div.p: The miseries of inforst marriage. As it is now played by his majesty's servants.
London printed for George Vincent, and are to be sold at his shop in Woodstreet. 1607.

div.head: The miseries of enforced marriage.
div.stage: Enter sir Francis Ilford, Wentloe, and Bartley.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: But Francke, Frank, now we are come to the house, what shall we make to be our business?

sp.speaker: Ilford.
sp.p: Tut, let us be impudent enough, and good enough.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: We have no acquaintance here, but young Scarborrow.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: How no acquaintance: angels guard me from thy company. I tell thee Wentloe thou art not worthy to wear guilt spurs, clean linen, nor good clothes.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Why for God's sake?

sp.speaker: Ilford.
sp.p: By this hand thou art not a man fit to table at an ordinary, keep knights company to bawdy houses, nor beggar thy tailor.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Why then I am free from cheaters, clear from the pox, and escape curses?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Why dost thou think there is any Christians in the world?

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: I and Jews too, brokers, Puritans, and sergeants.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Or dost thou mean to beg after charity, that goes in a cold suit already, that thou talkest thou hast no acquaintance here. I tell thee Wentloe thou canst not live on this side of the world: feed well, drink tobacco, and be honoured into the presence, but thou must be acquainted with all sorts of men, I and so far in to, till they desire to be more acquainted with thee.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: True, and than you shall be accounted a gallant of good credit.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: But stay, here is a scrape-trencher arrived: how now blue bottle, are you of the house?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I have heard of many black jacks sir, but never of a blue bottle.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Well sir, are you of the house?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: No sir, I am twenty yards without, and the house stands without me.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: Prithee tells who owes this building.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: He that dwells in it sir.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Who dwells in it then.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: He that owes it.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: What's his name.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I was none of his godfather.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Dus master Scarberow lie here,

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I'll give you a rhyme for that sir,
Sick men may lie, and dead men in their graves,
Few else do lie a-bed at noon, but drunkards, punks, and knaves.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: What am I the better for thy answer?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: What am I the better for thy question?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Why nothing.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Why then of nothing comes nothing.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Sblood this is a philosophical fool.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Then I that am a fool by art, am better than you that are fools by nature.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Gentlemen, welcome to Yorkshire.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: And well encountered my little villain of fifteen hundred a year, Stut what makest thou here in this barren soil of the North, when thy honest friends miss thee at London?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Faith gallants 'tis the country where my father lived, where first I saw the light, and where I am loved,

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Loved, I as courtier's love usurers, and that is just as long as they lend them money. Now dare I lay.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: None of your land good knight, for that is laid to mortgage already?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I dare lay with any man that will take me up.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Who list to have a lubberly load.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p:
Sirrah wag, this rogue was son and heir to Antony now, now, and blind moon. And he must needs be a scurvy musician, that hath two fiddlers to his fathers: but tell me in faith, art thou not, nay I know thou art called down into the country here, by some hoary knight or other, who knowing thee a young gentleman of good parts, and a great living ▪ hath desired thee to see some pitiful
piece of his workmanship, a daughter I mean, is't not, so?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: About some such preferment I came down.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Preferment, a good word: and when do you commence into the cuckold's order, the preferment you speak of when shall we have gloves: when, when?

sp.speaker: Scarb.
sp.l: Faith gallants
I have been guest here but since last night.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Why, and that is time enough to make up a dozen marriages, as marriages are made up now adays. For look you sir: the father according to the fashion, being sure you have a good living, and without encumbrance, comes to you thus: — takes you by the hand thus: — wipes his long beard thus: — or turns up his muchacho thus: — walks some turn or two thus: — to show his comely gravity thus: — and having washed his foul mouth thus: — it last breaks out thus. —

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: O God: let us hear more of this?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Master Scarborrow, you are a young gentleman, I knew your father well, he was my worshipful good neighbour, for our demeans lay near together. Then sir, — you and I must be of more near acquaintance. — at which, you must make an eruption thus: — oh God (Sweet sir)

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: 'Sfoot, the knight would have made an excellent zany, in an Italian comedy.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Then he goes forward thus: sir, myself am lord of some thousand a year, a widower, (Master Scarberrow) I have a couple of young gentlewomen to my daughters, a thousand a year will do well divided among them? Ha, wilt not master Scarborrow, — at which you out of your education must reply thus. — the portion will deserve them worthy husbands: on which tinder he soon takes fire and swears you are the man his hopes shot at, and one of them shall be yours.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: If I did not like her, should he swear to the devil, I would make him forsworn.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Then putting you and the young pugs to in a close room together.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: If he should lie with her there, is not the father partly the bawd?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p:
Where the young puppet, having the lesson before from
old fox, give the son half a dozen warm kisses, which after her father's oaths, takes such impression in thee, thou straight callest by Jesu mistress, I love you: — when she has the wit to ask, but sir, will you marry me, and thou in thy cox-sparrow-humor repliest, I (Before God) as I am a gentleman will I, which the father overhearing, leaps in, takes you at your word, swears he is glad to see this; nay he will have you contracted straight, and for a need makes the priest of himself.
sp.l: Thus in one hour, from a quiet life,
Thou art sworn in debt, and troubled with a wife.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: But can they love one another so soon?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: O, it is no matter now adays for love, 'tis well, and they can but make shift to lie together.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: But will your father do this too, if he know the gallant breathes himself at some two or three bawdy houses in a morning.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: O the sooner, for that and the land together, tell the old lad, he will know the better how to deal with his daughter?
sp.l: The wise and ancient fathers know this rule,
Should both wed maids, the child would be a fool.
sp.p: Come wag, if thou hast gone no further than into the ordinary fashion, meet, see, and kiss, give over: marry not a wife to have a hundred plagues for one pleasure: let's to London, there's variety: and change of pasture makes fat calves.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.p: But change of women bawld knaves, sir knight.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Wag and thou beest a lover but three days, thou wilt be heartless, sleepless, witless, mad, wretched, miserable, and indeed, a stark fool. And by that, thou hast been married but three weeks, though thou shouldst wed a Cynthia rara avis, thou wouldst be a man monstrous: a cuckold, a cuckold.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: And why is a cuckold monstrous, knight?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Why, because a man is made a beast by being married? Take but example thyself from the moon, as soon as she is delivered of her great belly, doth she not point at the world with a pair of horns, as who should say, married men, some of ye are cuckolds.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: I construe more divinely of their sex,
Being maids, methinks they are angels: and being wives,
They are sovereigns: cordials that preserve our lives,
they are like our hands that feed us, this is clear,
They renew man, as spring renews the year.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: There's ne'er a wanton wench that hears thee, but thinks thee a coxcomb for saying so: marry none of them, if thou wilt have their true characters, I'll give it thee, — women are the purgatory of men's purses, the paradise of their bodies, and the hell of their minds; marry none of them. Women are in churches saints, abroad angels, at home devils.
Here are married men enough, know this: marry none of them.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Men that traduce by custom, show sharp wit
Only in speaking ill, and practise it:
Against the best of creatures, divine women
Who are god's agents here, and the heavenly eye
By which this orb hath her maturity;
Beauty in women, get the world with child,
Without whom, she were barren, faint, and wild.
They are the stems on which do angels grow,
From whence virtue is styled, and arts do flow.

div.stage: Enter sir John Harcop and his daughter Clare.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Let them be what flowers they will, and they were roses, I will pluck none of them for pricking my fingers. But soft, here comes a voider for us: and I see, do what I can, as long as the world lasts, there will be cuckolds in it. Do you hear child, here's one come to blend you together: he has brought you a kneading-tub, if thou dost take her at his hands,
sp.l: Though thou hadst Argus eyes, be sure of this,
Women have sworn with more than one to kiss.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Nay no parting gentlemen: hem.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.l: 'Sfoot does he make punks of us, that he hems already?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Gallants,
Know old John Harcop keeps a wine-cellar,
Has travelled, been at court, known fashions,
And unto all bear's habit like yourselves,
The shapes of gentlemen and men of sort.
I have a health to give them ere they part.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Health knight, not as drunkards give their healths I hope, to go together by the ears when they have done?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: My healths are welcome: welcome gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Are we welcome knight, in faith.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Welcome in faith sir.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Prithee tell me hast not thou been a whoremaster.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: In youth I swill my fill at Venus' cup,
In stead of full draughts now I am fain to sup.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Why then thou art a man fit for my company:
Dost thou hear that he is a good fellow of our stamp,
Make much of his father.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: The father, and the gallants have left me hear with a gentlewoman, and if I know what to say to her I am a villain, heaven grant her life hath borrowed so much impudence of her sex, but to speak to me first: for by this hand, I have not so much steel of immodesty in my face, to parley to a wench without blushing. I'll walk by her, in hope she can open her teeth. — not a word? — is it not strange a man should be in a woman's company all this while and not hear her tongue. — I'll go further? — god of his goodness: not a syllable. I think if I should take up her clothes to, she would say nothing to me. — with what words trow dus a man begin to woe. Gentlewoman pray you what is't o'clock ?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Troth sir, carrying no watch about me but mine eyes, I answer you: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: And if you cannot tell, beauty I take the adage for my reply: you are naught to keep sheep.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Yet I am big enough to keep myself .

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Prithee tell me: are you not a woman?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: I know not that neither, till I am better acquainted with a man.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: And how would you be acquainted with a man?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: To distinguish betwixt himself and myself.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Why I am a man.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: That's more than I know sir.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: To approve I am no less: thus I kiss thee.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: And by that proof I am a man too, for I have kissed you.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Prithee tell me can you love?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: O lord sir, three or four things: I love my meat, choice of suitors: clothes in the fashion: and like a right woman I love to have my will.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: What think you of me for a husband?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Let me first know, what you think of me for a wife?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Troth I think you are a proper gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Do you but think so?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Nay I see you are a very perfect proper gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: It is great pity than I should be alone without a proper man.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Your father says I shall marry you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: And I say God forbid sir: I am a great deal too young.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I love thee by my troth.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: O pray you do not so, for then you stray from the steps of gentility, the fashion among them is to marry first, and love after by leisure.

sp.speaker: Scarb.
sp.p: That I do love thee, here by heaven I swear, and call it as a witness to this kiss.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: You will not enforce me I hope sir?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Makes me this woman's husband, thou art my Clare,
Accept my heart, and prove as chaste, as fair.

sp.speaker: Clare,
sp.p: O God, you are too hot in your gifts, should I accept them, we should have you plead nonage, some half a year hence: sue for reversement, and say the deed was done under age.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Prithee do not jest?

sp.speaker: Cl.
sp.p: No (God is my record) I speak in earnest: and desire to know whether ye mean to marry me, yea or no.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: This hand thus takes thee as my loving wife,

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: For better, for worse.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Ay, till death us depart love.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Why then I thank you sir, and now I am like to have that I long looked for: a husband.
sp.l: How soon from our own tongues is the word said,
Captives our maiden-freedom to a head.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Clare your are now mine, and I must let you know,
What every wife doth to her husband owe,
To be a wife, is to be dedicate
Not to a youthful course, wild, and unsteady,
But to the soul of virtue, obedience,
Studying to please, and never to offend.
Wiues, have two eyes created, not like birds
To roam about at pleasure, but for two sentinels,
To watch their husband's safety as their own,
two hands, ones to feed him, the other herself:
Two feet, and one of them is their husbands,
They have two of every thing, only of one,
Their chastity, that should be his alone.
Their very thoughts they cannot term them one,
Maids being once made wives, can nothing call
Rightly their own; they are their husbands all:
If such a wife you can prepare to be,
Clare I am yours: and you are fit for me.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: We being thus subdued, pray you know then,
As women owe a duty, so do men.
Men must be like the branch and bark to trees,
Which doth defend them from tempestuous rage,
Cloth them in winter, tender them in age,
Or as ewes love unto their eanlings lives,
Such should be husband's custom to their wives.
If it appear to them they have strayed amiss,
They only must rebuke them with a kiss,
Or clock them, as hen's chickens, with kind call,
Cover them under their wing, and pardon all:
No jars must make two beds, no strife divide them,
Those betwixt whom a faith and troth is given,
Death only parts, since they are knit by heaven:
If such a husband you intend to be,
I am your Clare, and you are fit for me.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: By heaven.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Advise before you swear, let me remember you,
Men never give their faith, and promise marriage,
But heaven records their oath: if they prove true,
Heaven smiles for joy, if not it weeps for you,
Unless your heart, then with your words agree,
Yet let us part, and less us both be free.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: If ever man in swearing love, swore true,
My words are like to his: here comes your father.

div.stage: Enter sir John Harcop, Ilford, Wentloe, Bartley, and Butler.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Now master Scarborrow.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Prepared to ask how you like that we have done,
Your daughters made my wife, and I your son.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: And both agreed so.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: We are sir,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Then long may you live together, have store of sons.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter who is the father.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: But son here is a man of yours is come from London.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: And brought you letters sir.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: What news from London butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: The old news sir, the ordinaries are full, some citizens are bankrupts, and many gentlemen beggars.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Clare here is an unwelcome pursuivant,
My lord and guardian writes to me with speed,
I must return to London.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: And you being ward to him son Scarborrow,
And know him great, it fits that you obey him.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: It does it does, for by an ancient law,
We are born free heirs, but kept like slaves in awe,
Who are for London gallants?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Switch and spur we will bear you company.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Clare I must leave thee, with what unwillingness
Witness this dwelling kiss upon thy lip,
And though I must be absent from thine eye,
Be sure my heart doth in thy bosom lie,
Three years I am yet a ward, which time I'll pass,
Making thy faith my constant looking-glass,
Till when.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Till when you please, where ere you live or lie,
Your loves here worn, your presence in my eye.

div.stage: Enter lord Faulconbridge, and sir William scarborow.

sp.speaker: Hunsd.
sp.l: Sir William,
How old say you is your kinsman Scarborrow.

sp.speaker: Will,
sp.l: Eighteen my lord, next Pentecost.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Bethink you good sir William,
I reckon thereabouts myself, so by that account
There's full three winters yet he must attend,
Under our awe, before he sue his livery:
Is't not so?

sp.speaker: Willi.
sp.l: Not a day less my lord.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Sir William you are his uncle, and I must speak
That am his guardian, would I had a son
Might merit commendations even with him.
I'll tell you what he is, he is a youth,
A noble branch, increasing blessed fruit.
Where caterpillar vice dare not to touch,
He is himself with so much gravity,
Praise cannot praise him with hyperbole:
He is one whom older look upon, as one a book,
Wherein are printed noble sentences
For them to rule their lives by. Indeed he is one
All emulate his virtues, hate him none.

sp.speaker: Willi.
sp.l: His friends are proud, to hear this good of him.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: And yet sir William being as he is,
Young, and unsettled, though of virtuous thoughts,
By genuine disposition, yet our eyes
See daily presidents, hopeful gentlemen,
Being trusted in the world with their own will,
Divert the good is looked from them to ill,
Make their old names forgotten, or not worth note
With company they keep, such revelling
With panders, parasites, podigies of knaves,
That they sell all, even their old father's graves.
Which to prevent, we'll match him to a wife,
Marriage restrains the scope of single life.

sp.speaker: Willi.
sp.l: My lord speaks like a father for my kinsman.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: And I have found him one of noble parentage,
A niece of mine, nay I have broke with her,
Know thus much of her mind, what for my pleasure
As also for the good appears in him,
She is pleased of all that's hers to make him King.

sp.speaker: Willi.
sp.p: Our name is blessed in such an honoured marriage

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Also I have appointed doctor Baxter,
Chancellor of Oxford to attend me here
And see he is come. Good master doctor.

sp.speaker: Bax.
sp.l: My honourable lord.

sp.speaker: Willi.
sp.l: I have possessed you with this business master doctor

sp.speaker: Baxt.
sp.p: To see the contract twixt you honoured niece and master Scarborrow.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: 'Tis so, and I did look for him by this.

sp.speaker: Bax.
sp.p: I saw him leave his horse as I came up.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: So, so.
Then he will be here forthwith: you master Baxter
Go usher hither straight young Katherine,
Sir William, here and I will keep this room till you return.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: My honourable lord.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: 'Tis well done Scarborrow.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Kind uncle.

sp.speaker: Willi.
sp.l: Thanks my good couz.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: You have been welcome in your country Yorkshire.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: The time that I spent there my lord was merry.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: 'Twas well, 'twas very well, and in your absence,
Your uncle here and I, have been bethinking
What gift betwixt us we might bestow on you,
That to your house large dignity might bring,
With fair increase, as from a crystal spring.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: My name is bound to your beneficence,
Your hands hath been to me like bounties purse,
Never shut up, yourself my foster-nurse:
Nothing can from your honour come; prove me so rude,
But I'll accept to shun ingratitude.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: We accept thy promise, now return thee this,
A virtuous wife, accept her with a kiss.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: My honourable lord.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Fear not to take her man, she will fear neither,
Do what thou canst being both a-bed together.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: O but my lord.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: But me a dog of wax, come kiss, and agree,
Your friends have thought it fit, and it must be.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: I have no hands to take her to my wife.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: How saucebox.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: O pardon me my lord the unripeness of my years,
Too green for government, is old in fears
To undertake that charge.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Sir, sir, I and sir knave, then here is a mellowed experience knows how to teach you,

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: O God.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: O Jack.
How both our cares, your uncle and myself,
Sought, studied, found out, and for your good,
A maid, a niece of mine, both fair and chaste,
And must we stand at your discretion.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: O good my lord
Had I two souls, then might I have two wives,
Had I two faiths, then had I one for her,
Having of both but one, that one is given
To sir John Harcops daughter.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Ha, ha, what's that, let me hear that again?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: To sir John Harcops Clare I have made an oath,
Part me in twain, yet she's one half of both.
This hand the which I wear it is half hers,
Such power hath faith and troth twixt couples young,
Death only cuts that knot tide with the tongue.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: And have you knit that knot sir.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: I have done so much, that if I wed not her,
My marriage makes me an adulterer,
In which black sheets, I wallow all my life,
My babes being bastards, and a whore my wife.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Ha, is't even so, my secretary there,
Write me a letter straight to sir John Harcop,
I'll see sir Jack and if that Harcop dare,
Being my ward, contract you to his daughter.
My steward too, post you to Yorkshire,
Where lies my youngsters land, and sirrah,
Fell me his wood, make havoc, spoil and waste.
Sir you shall know that you are ward to me,
I'll make you poor enough: then mend yourself.

sp.speaker: Vvill.
sp.l: O cousin.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: O uncle.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Contract yourself and where you list,
I'll make you know me sir to be your guard.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: World now thou seest what 'tis to be a ward.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: And where I meant myself to have disbursed
Four thousand pound, upon this marriage
Surrendered up your land to your own use,
And compassed other portions to your hands,
Sir I'll now yoke you still.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: A yoke indeed.

sp.speaker: Huns.
sp.l: And spite of they dare contradict my will,
I'll make thee marry to my chambermaid. Come cousin.

sp.speaker: Bax.
sp.l: Faith sir it fits you to be more advised.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Do not you flatter for preferment sir

sp.speaker: Willi.
sp.l: O but good coz.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: O but good uncle could I command my love,
Or cancel oaths out of heaven's brazen book,
Engrossed by gods own finger, than you might speak.
Had men that law to love as most have tongues
To love a thousand women with, than you might speak.
Were love like dust lawful for every wind,
To bear from place to place, were oaths but puffs,
Men might forswear themselves, but I do know,
Though sin being passed with us, the acts forgotten,
The poor soul groans, and she forgets it not.

sp.speaker: Willi.
sp.l: Yet hear your own case?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: O 'tis to miserable:
That I a gentleman should be thus torn
From mine own right, and forest to be forsworn.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.l: Yet being as it is, it must be your care,
To salve it with advice, not with despair,
You are his ward, being so, the law intends,
He is to have your duty, and in his rule
Is both your marriage, and your heritage,
If you rebel against these injunctions,
The penalty takes hold on you, which for himself,
He straight thus prosecutes, he wastes your land,
Weds you where he thinks fit, but if yourself
Have of some violent humour matched yourself,
Without his knowledge, then hath he power
To merce your purse, and in a sum so great,
That shall for ever keep your fortunes weak,
Where otherwise if you be ruled by him
your house is raised by matching to his kin.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Now death of me, shall I be crossed by such a Jack, he wed
Himself, and where he list: sirrah Malapart, I'll hamper you,
You that will have your will, come get you in:
I'll make thee shape thy thoughts to marry her,
Or wish thy birth had been thy murderer.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Fare pity me, because I am enforced,
For I have heard those matches have cost blood,
Where love is once begun and then withstood,

div.stage: Enter Ilford and a page with him.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Boy, hast thou delivered my letter?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I sir, I saw him open the lips on't.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: He had not a new suit on, had he?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I am not so well acquainted with his wardrobe sir, but I saw a lean fellow, with sunk eyes, and shamble legs, sigh pitifully at his chamber door, and entreat his man to put his master in mind of him.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: O, that was his tailor, I see now he will be blessed he profits by my counsel, he will pay no debts before he be arrested, nor then neither, if he can find ere a beast that dare but be bail for him, but he will seal i'th afternoon.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes sir, he will imprint for you as deep as he can.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Good, good, now have I a parson's nose, and smell tithe coming in then. Now let me number how many rooks I have half undone already this term by the first return: four by dice, six by being bound with me, and ten by queans, of which some be courtiers, some country gentlemen, and some citizens' sons. Thou art a good Frank, if thou pe●gest thus, thou art still a companion for gallants, mayst keep a catamite, take physic, at the spring and the fall.

sp.speaker: Wont.
sp.p: Frank, news that will make thee fat Frank.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Prithee rather give me somewhat will keep me lean,
I ha' no mind yet to take physic.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Master Scarberrow is a married man.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Then heaven grant he may, as few married men do, make much of his wife.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Why? wouldst have him love her, let her command all, and make her his master?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: No no, they that do so, make not much of their wives, but give them their will, and it's the marring of 'em.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: Honest Frank, valorous Francke, a portion of thy wit, but to help us in this enterprise, and we may walk London street and cry pish at the sergeants.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: You may shift out one term, and yet die in the counter, these are the scabs now that hang upon honest Job, I am Job, and these art the scurvy scabs, but what's this your pot seethes over withal?

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: Master Scarborrow is a married man.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: He has all his land in his own hand.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: His brothers and sister's portions.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Besides four thousand pound in ready money with his wife.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: A good talon by my faith, it might help many gentlemen to pay their tailors, and I might be one of them.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Nay, honest Frank, hast thou found a trick for him, if thou hast not, look here's a line to direct thee. First draw him into bands for money, then to dice for it: then take up stuff at the mercers, straight to a punk with it: then mortgage his land, and be drunk with that: so with them and the rest, from an ancient gentleman, make him a young beggar.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: What a rogue is this, to read a lecture to me, and mine own lesson too, which he knows I ha' made perfect to 9 hundred fourscore and nineteen. A cheating rascal will teach me that ha' made them that have worn a spacious park, lodge and all of their backs this morning: been fain to pawn it afore night, and they that ha' stalked like a huge elephant, with a castle on their necks, and removed that to their own shoulders in one day which their fathers built up in seven year, been glad by my means, in so much time as a child sucks, to drink bottle ale, though a punk pay fort. And shall this parrot instruct me?

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Nay but Frank.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p:
A rogue that hath fed upon me, and the fruit of my wit like pullen from a pantler's chipings, and now I put him into good clothes to shift two suits in a day, that could scare shift a patched shirt once
in a year, and says prayers when he had it: hark, how he prates.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Besides Frank, since his marriage, he stalks me like a cashiered captain discontent, in which melancholy, the jest drop of mirth, of which thou hast an ocean, will make him, and all his ours for ever.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Says mine own rogue so, give me thy hand then, we'll do't, and there's earnest. Strikes him. 'sfoot you chitty-face, that looks worse than a collier through a wooden window, an ape afeard of a whip, or a knave's head, shook seven years in the weather upon London-bridge. Do you catechise me?

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Nay but valorous Frank, he that knows the secrets of all hearts, knows I did it in kindness.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Know your seasons: besides, I am not of that species for you to instruct. Then know your seasons.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: 'Sfoot friends, friends, all friends: here comes young Scarborrow, should he knew of this, all our designs were prevented.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: What, melancholy my young master, my young married man, God give your worship joy.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Joy, of what Frank?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Of thy wealth, for I hear of few that ha' joy of heir wives

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Who weds as I have to enforced sheets,
His care increaseth, but his comfort fleets.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Thou having so much wit, what a devil meantst thou to marry?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: O speak not of it,
Marriage sounds in mine care like a bell,
Not rung for pleasure, but a doleful knell.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: A common course, those men that are married in the morning, to wish themselves buried ere night.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I cannot love her.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: No news neither, wives know that's a general fault amongst their husbands.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I will not lie with her.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Cetera volunt she'll say still, if you will not, another will.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Why did she marry me, knowing I did not love her.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: As other women do, either to be maintained by you, or to make you a cuckold. Now sir, what come you for?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: As men do in haste, to make an end of their business.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: What's your business?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: My business is this sir, this sir, and this sir,

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: The meaning of all this sir. Cl. by this is as much as to say sir, may Mai. has sent unto you. By this is as much as to say sir, my master has him humbly commended unto you, and by this is as much as to say, my master craves your answer.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Give me your letter. And you shall have this sir, this sir, and this sir.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: No sir.

sp.speaker: Ilford.
sp.p: Why sir?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Because as the learned have very well instructed me, qui supranos, nihil ad nos, and though many gentlemen will have to do with other men's business, yet from me know, the most part of them prove knaves for their labour.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: You ha' the knave i'faith Frank.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Long may he live to enjoy it. From sir John Harcop of Harcop, in the county of York knight, by me his man, to yourself my young master, by these presents greeting.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: How camest thou by these good words?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: As you by your good clothes, took them upon trust, and swore I would never pay for 'em.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Thy master sir John Harcop writes to me,
That I should entertain thee for my man,
His wish is acceptable, thou art welcome fellow.
O but thy master's daughter, sends an article
Which makes me think upon my present sin,
Here she remembers me to keep in mind
My promised faith to her, which I ha' broke.
Here she remembers me I am a man,
Black tore with perjury, whose sinful breast,
Is charactered like those cursed of the blessed.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: How now my young bully, like a young wench forty weeks after the loss of her maidenhead, crying out.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Trouble me not,
Give me pen, ink, and paper, I will write to her,
O? But what shall I write?
Mine own excuse, why no excuse can serve
For him that swears, and from his oath doth swerve?
Or shall I say, my marriage was in so rest,
'Twas bad in them, not well in me to yield.
Wretched thee to whose marriage was compelled,
I'll only write that which my grave hath bred,
Forgive me Clare, for I am married:
'Tis soon set down, but not so soon forgotten, or worn from hence.
Deliver it unto her, there's for thy pains,
Would I as soon could cleanse these perjured stains.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Well, I could alter mine eyes from filthy mud into fair water: you have paid for my tears, and mine eyes shall prove bankrupts, and break out for you, let no man persuade me, I will cry, and every town betwixt shoreditch-church and York bridge, shall bear me witness.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Gentlemen, I'll take my leave of you,
She that I am married to but not my wife,
Will London leave, in Yorkshire lead our life.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: We must not leave you so my young gallant,
We three are sick in state, and your wealth must help to make us whole again.
For this saying, is as true as old:
Strife nursed twixt man and wife, makes such a flaw,
How great so e're's their wealth, 'twill have a thaw,

div.stage: Enter sir John Harcop with his daughter Clare, and two younger brothers, Thomas, and John Scarborrow.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Brothers to him ere long shall be my son,
By wedding this young girl: you are welcome both,
Nay kiss her, kiss, though that she shall
Be your brother's wife, to kiss the cheek is free.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Kiss, 'sfoot what else? thou art a good plump wench, I like you well, prithee make haste and bring store of boys, but be sure they have good faces, that they may call me uncle.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Glad of so fair a sister, I salute you.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Good, good i'faith, this kissings good i'faith,
I loved to smack it too when I was young,
But mum: they have felt thy cheek Clare, let them hear thy tongue.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Such welcome as befits my Scarborrow's brothers,
From me his troth-plight wife be sure to have,
And though my tongue prove scant in any part,
The bounds be sure are large, full in my heart.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Tut, that's not that we doubt on wench, but do you hear sir John, what do you think drew me from London, and the inns of court, thus far into Yorkshire?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: I guess to see this girl, shall be your sister.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Faith, and I guess partly so too, but the main was, and I will not lie to you, that your coming now in this wise into our kindred, I might be acquainted with you aforehand, that after my brother had married your daughter, I his brother might borrow some money of you.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: What? Do you borrow of your kindred sir?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.p: 'Sfoot what else, they having interest in my blood, why should not I have interest in their coin. Besides sir, I being a younger brother, would be ashamed of my generation if I would not borrow of any man that would lend, especially of my affinity, of whom I keep a calendar. And look you sir, thus I go over them. Frst o'er my uncles, often o'er mine ants, then up to my nephews, straight down to my nieces, to this cousin Thomas, and that cousin Jeffrey, leaving the courteous claw given to none of their elbows, even unto the third and fourth remove of any that hath interest in our blood. All which do upon their summons made by me, duly and faithfully provide for appearance, and so as they are, I hope we shall be, more endeared, entirely, better, and more feelingly acquainted.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You are a merry gentleman.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: 'Tis the hope of money makes me so, and I know none but fools use to be sad with it.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: From Oxford am I drawn, from serious studies
Expecting that my brother still had sojourned
With you his best of choice, and this good knight.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: His absence shall not make our hearts less merry
Than if we had his presence. A day ere long,
Will bring him back, when one the other meets,
At noon i'th church, at night between the sheets.
We'll wash this chat with wine. Some wine: fill up,
The sharpener of the wit, is a full cup.
And so to you sir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Do, and I'll drink, to my new sister, but upon this condition, that she may have quiet days, little rest a nights, ha' pleasant afternoons, be pliant to my brother, and lend me money whensoe'er I'll borrow it.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Nay, nay, nay,
Women are weak and we must bear with them,
Your frolic healths, are only fit for men,

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Well, I am contented, women must to the wall, though it be to a featherbed. Fill up then.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: From London am I come, though not with pipe and drum,
Yet I bring matter, in this poor paper,
Will make my young mistress, delighting in kisses,
Do as all maidens will, hearing of such an ill,
As to have lost, the thing they wished most,
A husband, a husband, a pretty sweet husband,
Cry o, o, o, and alas, and at last ho, ho, ho, as I do.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Returned so soon from London? What's the news?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: O mistress, if ever you have seen Demonicea clear look into mine eyes, mine eyes are Severn, plain Severn, the Thames, nor the river of Tweed are nothing to 'em: nay all the rain that fell at Noah's flood, had not the discretion that my eyes have: that drunk but up the whole world, and I ha' drowned all the way betwixt this and London.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Thy news good robin.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: My news mistress, I'll tell you strange news, the dust upon London way, being so great, that not a lord, gentleman, knight, or knave could travel, lest his eyes should be blown out: at last, they all agreed to hire me to go before them, when I looking but upon this letter, did with this water, this very water, lay the dust, as well as if it had reigned from the beginning of April to the last of may.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: A letter from my Scarborrow, give it thy mistress.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: But mistress.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Prithee be gone,
I would not have my father nor this gentlemen,
Be witness of the comfort it doth bring.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: O but mistress.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Prithee begone,
With this, and the glad news, leave me alone.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: 'Tis your turn knight, take your liquor, know I am bountiful, I'll forgive any man any thing that he owes me, but his drink, and that I'll be paid for.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: May gentlemen the honesty of mirth
Consists not in carousing with excess,
My father hath more welcomes then in wine:
Pray you no more.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Says my sister so, I'll be ruled by thee then. Do you hear, in hope hereafter you'll lend me some money, now we are half drunk let's go to dinner. Come knight.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I am glad your gone,
Shall I now open't: no, I'll kiss it first,
Because his outside last did kiss his hand.
Within this fouled, I'll call't a sacred sheet,
Are writ black lines, when our white hearts shall meet,
Before I open this door of my delight,
Methinks I guess how kindly he doth write,
Of his true love to me, as chuck, sweetheart,
I prithee do not think the time too long,
That keeps us from the sweets of marriage rites,
And then he sets my name and kisses it,
Wishing my lips his sheet to write upon,
With like desire methinks as mine own thoughts,
Ask him now here for me to look upon,
Yet at the last thinking his love too slack,
Ere it arrive at my desired eyes,
He hastens up his message with like speed,
Even as I break this ope, wishing to read:
O: what's hear? Mine eyes are not mine own? sure they're not,
Though you ha' been my lamps this sixteen years,
You do belie, my Scarborrow reading so;
Forgive him, he is married, that were ill:
What lying lights are these. Look I ha' no such letter,
No wedded syllable of the least wrong
Done to a troth-plight-virgin like myself ▪
Beshrew you for your blindness: forgive him, he is married.
I know my Scarborough's constancy to me,
Is as firm knit, as faith to charity,
That I shall kiss him often, hug him thus,
Be made a happy and a fruitful mother
Of many prosperous children like to him,
and read I, he was married? Asked forgiveness?
What a blind fool was I? yet here's a letter
To whom directed trow? To my beloved Clare.
Why la?
Women will read, and read not that they saw,
'Twas but my fervent love misled mine eyes,
I'll once again to the inside, forgive me, I am married:
William Scarborrow. He has set his name to't to,
Oh perjury? within the hearts of men
Thy feasts are kept, their tongues proclaimeth them.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Sister, God's precious, the clothes laid, the meat cools, we all stay, and your father calls for you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Kind sir, excuse me I pray you a little,
I'll but peruse this letter and come straight.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Pray you make haste, the meat stays for us, and our stomach ▪
Ready for the meat, for believe this,
Drink makes men hungry, or it makes them lie,
And he that's drunk o'er night, ith' morning's dry,
Seen and approved.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: He was contracted mine, yet he unjust
Hath married to another: what's my estate then?
A wretched maid, not fit for any man,
For being united his with plighted faiths,
Whoever sues to me commits a sin,
Besiegeth me, and who shall marry me:
Is like myself, lives in adultery, (Oh God)
That such hard fortune, should betide my youth.
I am young, fair, rich, honest, virtuous,
Yet for all this, who ere shall marry me
I am but his where, live in adultery.
I cannot step into the path of pleasure
For which I was created, born unto,
Let me live never so honest, rich or poor,
If I once wed, yet I must live a whore.
I must be made a strumpet 'gainst my will,
A name I have abhorred, a shameful ill
I have eschewed, and now cannot withstand it
In myself. I am my father's only child,
in me he hath a hope, though not his name
Can be increased, yet by my issue
His land shall be possessed, his age delighted.
And though that I should vow a single life
To keep my soul unspotted, yet will he
Enforce me to a marriage:
So that my grief doth of that weight consist,
It helps me not to yield, nor to resist:
And was I then created for a whore? A whore,
Bad name, bad act, bad man makes me a scorn:
Then live a strumpet? Better be unborn.
Sister, pray you will you come,
Your father and the whole meeting stays for you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: I come, I come, I pray return: I come.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: I must not go without you.

sp.speaker: Clare,
sp.l: Be thou my usher, sooth I'll follow you

div.l: He writes here to forgive him, he is married:
False gentleman: I do forgive thee with my heart,
Yet will I send an answer to thy letter,
And in so short words thou shalt weep to read them,
And hears my agent ready: forgive me, I am dead.
'Tis writ, and I will act it: be judge you maids
Have trusted the false promises of men.
Be judge you wives, the which have been enforced
From the white sheets you loved, to them ye loathed:
Whether this axiom may not be assured,
Better one sin, than many be endured.
My arms embracings, kisses, chastity,
Were his possessions: and whilst I live
He doth but steal those pleasures he enjoys,
Is an adulterer in his married arms,
And never goes to his defiled bed,
But God writes sin upon the tasters head.
I'll be a wife now, help to save his soul
Though I have lost his body, give a slake
To his iniquities, and with one sin
Done by this hand, end many done by him.
Farewell the world, then farewell the wedded joys
till this I have hoped for, from that gentleman,
Scarborrow, forgive me: thus thou hast lost thy wife,
Yet record would, though by an act too foul,
A wife thus did to cleanse her husband's soul.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: God's precious, for his mercy, where's this wench?
Must all my friends and guests attend on you?
Where are you minion?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Scarborrow come close mine eyes, for I am dead.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: That sad voice was not hers I hope:
Who's this, my daughter?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.l: Your daughter,
That begs of you to see her buried,
Prays Scarborrow to forgive her: she is dead.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Patience good tears, and let my words have way
Clare, my daughter, help my servants there:
Lift up thine eyes, and look upon thy father,
They were not born to lose their light so soon,
I did beget thee for my comforter,
And not to be the author of my care.
Why speakst thou not? Some help my servants there:
What hand hath made thee pale? Or if thine own,
What cause hadst thou that wert thy father's joy,
The treasure of his age, the cradle of his sleep,
His all in all? I prithee speak to me?
Thou art not ripe for death, come back again,
Clare, my Clare, if death must needs have one,
I am the fittest, prithee let me go,
Thou dying whilst I live, I am dead with woe.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: What means this outcry?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: O ruthful spectacle.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Thou wert not wont to be so sullen child,
But kind and loving to thy aged father:
Awake, awake, if't be thy lasting sleep,
Would I had not sense for grief, nor eyes to weep.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: What papers this, the sad contents doth tell me,
My brother writ, he hath broke his faith to her,
And she replies, for him she hath killed herself.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Was that the cause that thou hast soiled thyself,
With these red spots, these blemishers of beauty?
My child, my child, was't perjury in him,
Made thee so fair, act now so foul a fin,
That he deceived thee in a mother's hopes,
Posterity, the bliss of marriage?
Thou hast no tongue to answer no, or I,
But in red letters writes: for him I die.
Curse on his traitorous tongue, his youth, his blood,
His pleasures, children, and possessions,
Be all his days like winter, comfortless:
Restless his nights, his wants remorseless,
And may his corpse be the physician's stage,
Which played upon, stands not to honoured age,
Or with diseases may he lie and pine,
Till grief wastes blood, his eyes, as grief doth mine.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: O good old man, made wretched by this deed,
The more thy age, were to be pitied.

div.stage: Enter Scarborrow, his wife Katherine, Ilford, Wentlo, barley and Butler.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: What ride by the gate, and not call, that were a shame i'faith.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: We'll but taste of his beer, kiss his daughter, and to horse again, where's the good knight hear?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: You bring me to my shame unwillingly.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Shamed of what, for deceiving of a wench, I ha' not blushed,
That ha' dunt to a hundred of 'em.
In women's love he's wise, doth follow this,
Love one so long till her another kiss.
Where's the good knight here?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: O brother, you are come to make your eye
Sad mourner at a fatal tragedy.
Peruse this letter first, and then this corpse.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: O wronged Clare? Accursed Scarborrow?
I writ to her, that I was married,
She writes to me, forgive her she is dead:
I'll balm thy body with my faithful tears,
And be perpetual mourner at thy tomb,
I'll sacrifice this commit into sighs,
make a consumption of this pile of man,
And all the benefits my parents gave,
Shall turn distempered to appease the wrath
For this blood shed, and I am guilty of.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Dear husband.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: False woman, not my wife, though married to me,
Look what thy friends, and thou art guilty of,
The murder of a creature, equalled heaven
In her creation, whose thoughts like fire,
Never looked base, but ever did aspire
To blessed benefits, till you and yours undid her,
Eye her, view, though dead, yet she does look,
Like a fresh frame, or a new printed book
Of the best paper, never looked into,
But with one sullied finger, which did spot her,
Which was her own too, but who was cause of it,
Thou and thy friends, and I will loathe thee fort.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: They do bely her that do say she's dead,
She is but strayed to some by-gallery,
And I must ha' her again. Clare, where art thou Clare?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Here, laid to take her everlasting sleep.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: A lies that says so,
Yet now I know thee, I do lie that say it,
For if she be a villain like thyself,
A perjured traitor, recreant, miscreant,
Dog, a dog, a dog, has dunt.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: O sir John Harcop.

sp.speaker: Hra.
sp.l: O sir John villain, to be troth thyself
To this good creature, harmless, harmless child,
This kernel hope, and comfort of my house,
Without enforcement, of thine own accord,
Draw all her soul ith' compass of an oath,
Take that oath from her, make her for none but thee,
And then betray her?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Shame on them were the cause of it.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: But hark what thou hast got by it,
Thy wife is but a strumpet, thy children bastards,
thyself a murderer, thy wife, accessory,
Thy bed a stews, thy house a brothel.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: O, 'tis too true.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Ay, made a wretched father childless.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Ay, made a married man, yet wifeless.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Thou the cause of it.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Thou the cause of it.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Curse on the day that ere it was begun,
For I an old man am, undone, undone.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: For charity have care upon your father,
Lest that his grief, bring on a more mishap,
This to my arms, my sorrow shall bequeath,
Though I have lost her, to thy grave I'll bring,
Thou wert my wife, and I'll thy requiem sing:
Go you to the country, I'll to London back,
All riot now, since that my souls so black.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Thus am I left like sea-tost-marriners,
My fortunes being no more than my distress,
Upon what shore soever I am driven,
Be it good or bad, I must account it heaven,
Though married, I am reputed not a wife,
Neglected of my husband, scorned, despised,
And though my love and true obedience
Lies prostrate to his beck, his heedless eye,
Receives my services unworthily.
I know no cause, nor will be cause of none,
But hope for better days when bad be gone,
You are my guide, whether must I, Butler?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Towards Wakefield, where my masters living lies.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Towards Wakefield where thy master we'll attend,
When things are at the worst, 'tis hoped they'll mend.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: How now sister, no further forward on your journey yet?

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: When griefs before one, who'd go on to grief,
I'd rather turn me back to find some comfort.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: And that way sorrows hurtfuller than this,
My brother having brought unto a grave,
That murthered body whom he called his wife,
and spent so many tears upon her hearse,
As would have made a tyrant to relent,
Then kneeling at her coffin, thus he vowed,
From thence he never would embrace your bed.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: The more fool he.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Never from hence acknowledge you his wife,
When others strive to enrich their father's name,
It should be his only aim, to beggar his,
To spend their means, and in his only pride,
Which with a sigh confirmed, he's rid to London,
Vowing a course, that by his life so foul
Men ne'er should join the hands, without the soul.

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: All is but grief, and I am armed for it.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: We'll bring you on your way in hope that's strong
Time may at length make straight. what yet is wrong.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: He's our own, he's our own, come, let's make use of his wealth, as the snow of ice: melt it, melt it.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: But art sure he will hold his meeting.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: As sure as I am now, and was dead drunk last night.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Why then so sure will I be arrested by a couple of sergeants, and fall into one of the unlucky cranks about Cheapside, called counters.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Withal, I have provided m. gripe the usurer, who upon the instant will be ready to step in, charge the sergeants to keep thee fast, and that now he will have his five hundered pounds, or thou shalt rot for it.

sp.speaker: Went:
sp.p: When it follows, young Scarborow shall be bound for the one: then take up as much more, we share the one half, and help him to be drunk with the other.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Why, dost laugh Frank?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: To see that we and usurer's line by the fall of young heirs as swine by the dropping of acorns. But he's come. Where be these rogues? shall we ha' no tendance here?

sp.speaker: Scarb.
sp.p: Good day gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p:
A thousand good days, my noble bully, and as many good fortunes as there were grasshoppers in Egypt, and that's covered
over with good luck: but nouns, pronouns, and participles. Where be these rogues here: what, shall we have no wine here?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Anon, anon, sir.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Anon, goodman rascal, must we stay your leisure? gi't us by and by, with a pox to you.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: O, do not hurt the fellow?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Hurt him, hang him, scrape-trencher, star-warren, wine spiller, metal-clancker, rogue by generation. Why, dost hear will? If thou dost not use these grape-spiller as you do their pottle-pots, quoit 'em down stairs three or four times at a supper, they le grow as saucy with you as sergeants, and make bills more unconscionable than tailors.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Here's the pure and neat grape gent. I hate for you.

sp.speaker: Ilford.
sp.p: Fill up: what ha' you brought here, goodman rogue?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: The pure element of claret sir.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Ha you so, and did not I call for Rhenish you mongrel?

div.stage: Throws the wine in the drawers face.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Thou needst no wine, I prithee be more mild?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Be mild in a tavern, 'tis treason to the red lettice, enemy to their sign post, and slave to humour:
sp.l: Prithee, let's be mad,
Then fill our heads with wine, till every pate be drunk,
Then piss i'the street, jostle all you meet, and with a punk,
As thou wilt do now and then: thank me thy good
Master, that brought thee to it.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Nay, he profits well, but the worst is he will not swear yet

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Do not belie me: if there be any good in me that's the best: oaths are necessary for nothing, they pass out of a man's mouth, like smoke through a chimney, that files all the way it goes.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Why then I think tobacco be a kind of swearing, for it furs our nose pockily.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: But come, let's drink ourselves into a stomach afore supper.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Agreed. I'll begin with a new health. Fill up.

div.l: To them that make land fly,
By wine, whores, and a die.
To them, that only thrives,
By kissing others wives.
To them that pay for clothes,
With nothing but with oaths:
Care not from whom they get,
So they may be in debt:
This health my hearts
But who their tailors pay,
Borrow, and keep their day,
We'll hold him like this glass,
A brainless empty ass,
And not a mate for us.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: An excellent health.
Master Ilford, there's a couple of strangers beneath desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: What beards ha' they? Gentleman-like-beards, or broker-like-beards?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: I am not so well acquainted with the art of face mending sir: but they would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I'll go down to 'em.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Do: and we'll stay here and drink tobacco.

sp.speaker: Scarb.
sp.l: Thus like a fever that doth shake a man
From strength to weakness, I consume myself:
I know this company, their custom vild,
Hated, abhorred of goodmen, yet like a child
By reason's rule instructed how to know
Evil from good, I to the worser go.
Why do you suffer this, you upper powers,
That I should surfeit in the sin I taste, have sense to feel my mischief, yet make waste
Of heaven and earth:
Myself will answer, what myself doth ask?
Who once doth cherish sin, begets his shame,
For vice being fostered once, coms impudence,
Which makes men count sin, custom, not offence,
When all like me, their reputation blot,
Pursuing evil, while the good 〈◊〉 got.

div.stage: Enter Ilford led in by a couple of sergeants, and Gripe the usurer.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Nay, never strive, we can hold you.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Ay, me, and any man else, and a fall into your clutches: let go your tugging, as I am a gentleman, I'll be your true prisoner.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: How now: what's the matter Frank?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I am fallen into the hands of sergeants, I am arrested.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: How, arrest a gentleman in our company?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Put up, put up, for sins sake put up, let's not all sup in the counter tonight , let me speak with master gripe the creditor.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Well: what say you to me sir?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: You have arrested me here master gripe.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Not I sir, the sergeants have.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: But at your suit master gripe: yet hear me, as I am a gent.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: I rather you could say as you were an honest man, and then I might believe you.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Yet hear me.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Hear me no hearings, I lent you my money for good will.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: And I spent it for mere necessity, I confess I owe you five hundred pound, and I confess I owe not a penny to any man, but he would be glad to hate: my bond you have already master gripe if you will, now take my word.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Word me no words: officers look to your prisoner: if you cannot either make me present payment, or put me in security such as I shall like too.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Such as you shall like too: what say you to this young gent. He is the widgen that we must feed upon.

sp.speaker: Grip.
sp.p: Who young master Scarborrow, he is an honest gentleman for ought I know, I ne'er lost penny by him.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I would be ashamed any man should say so by me, that I have had dealings withal: but my enforced friends, wilt please you but to retire into some small distance, whilst I descend with a few words to these gentlemen, and I'll commit myself into your hands immediately.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: Well sir we'll wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p:
Gentlemen I am to proffer some conference, and in especially to you master Scarborrow, our meeting here for your mirth hath proved to me thus adverse, that in your companies I am arrested: how ill it will stand with the flourish of your reputations when men of rank and note communicate, that I Frank Ilford, gentleman. whose fortunes may transcend, to make ample gratuities
future, and heap satisfaction for any present extension of his friend's kindness, was enforced from the mitre in Bredstreet, to the counter ith' poultry: for mine own part, if you shall think it meet, and that it shall accord with the state of gentry, to submit myself from the featherbed in the master's side, or the flock-bed in the knight's ward, to the straw-bed in the hole, I shall buckle to my heels instead of guilt spurs, the armour of patience, and do't.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Come, come, what a pox need all this, this is mellis Flora, the sweetest of the honey, he that was not made to fat cattle, but to feed gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: You wear good clothes.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Are well descended.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: Keep the best company.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Should regard your credit.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Stand not upon't, be bound, be bound.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Ye are richly married.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Love not your wife.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Have store of friends.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Who shall be your heir.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: The son of some slave.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Some groom.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Some horsekeeper.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: Stand not upon't, be bound, be bound.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Well at your importance, for once I'll stretch my purse whose born to sink, as good this way as worse.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Now speaks my bully like a gentleman of worth.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: Of merit.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Fit to be regarded.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: That shall command our souls.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Our swords.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: Ourselves.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: To feed upon you as Pharaoh's lean kine did upon the fat.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Master gripe is my bond currant for this gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Good security you Egyptian grasshopper, good security?

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: And for as much more kind master Scarborrow.
Provided that men mortal as we are,
May have.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: May have security.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.p: Your bond with land conveyed, which may assure me of mine own again.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: You shall be satisfied, and I'll become your debtor, for full five hundred more than he doth owe you.
sp.l: This night we sup here, bear us company,
And bring your counsel, scrivener, and the money with you,
Where I will make as full assurance as in the law you'd wish.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: I take your word sir,
And so discharge you of your prisoner.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Why then let's come and take up a new room, the infected hath spit in this.
sp.l: He that hath store of coin, wants not a friend,
Thou shalt receive sweet rogue, and we will spend.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Brother, you see the extremity of want
Enforceth us to question for our own,
The rather that we see, not like a brother
Our brother keeps from us to spend on other.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: True, he has in his hands our portions, the patrimony which our father gave us, with which he lies fatting himself with sack and sugar in the house, and we are fain to walk with lean purses abroad. Credit must be maintained which will not be without money, good clothes must be had, which will not be without money, company must be kept which will not be without money, all which we must have, and from him we will have money.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Besides, we have brought our sister to this town,
That she herself having her own from him,
Might bring herself in court to be preferred,
Under some noble personage, or else that he
Whose friends are great in court, by his late match,
As he is in nature bound, provide for her.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: And he shall do it brother, though we have waited at his lodging, longer than a tailor's bill on a young knight for an old rekoning, without speaking with him, here we know he is, and we will call him to parley.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Yet let us do't in mild and gentle terms,
Fair words perhaps may sooner draw our own,
Then rougher courses by which his mischief grown.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Anon, anon, look down into the dolphin there.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Here comes a drawer we will question him.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Do you hear my friend, is not master Scarborrow here?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Here sir, what a jest is that, where should he be else, I would have you well know my master hopes to grow rich before he leaves him.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: How long hath he continued here since he came hither.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Faith sir not so long as Noah's flood, yet long enough to have drowned up the livings of three knights, as knights goes now adays, some month or thereabouts .

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Time ill consumed to ruinate our house,
But what are they that keep him company?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Pitch, pitch, but I must not say so, but for your further satisfaction, did you ever see a young whelp and a lion play together.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Such is master Scarborrow's company
Within Oliver.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: Anon, anon, look down to the pomgranate there.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: I prithee say here's them would speak with him.

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.p: I'll do your message: anon, anon there.

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: This fool speaks wiser than he is aware,
Young heirs left in this town where sins so rank,
And prodigals gape to grow fat by them,
Are like young whelps thrown in the lion's den,
Who play with them awhile, at length devour them.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Who's there would speak with me?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Your brothers, who are glad to see you well.

sp.speaker: Scar,
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: 'Tis not your riot, that we hear you use,
(With such as waste their goods, as time the world
With a continual spending, nor that you keep
The company of a most leprous rout,
Consumes your body's wealth, infects your name
With such plague-sores, that had you reasons eye,
'Twould make you sick, to see you visit them)
Hath drawn us, but our wants to crave the dew
Our father gave, and yet remains with you.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p:
Our birthright good brother, this town craves maintenance,
silk stockings must be had, and we would be loath our heritage should be arraigned at the vintner's bar, and so condemned to the vintner's box, though while you did keep house, we had some belly-timber at your table, or so, yet we would have you think, we are your brothers, yet no Esau's to sell our patrimony for porridge.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: So, so, what hath your coming else?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: With us our sister joins in our request,
Whom we have brought along with us to London,
To have her portion, wherewith to provide,
An honoured service, or an honest bride.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: So, than you two my brothers, and she my sister, come not as in duty you are bound, to an elder brother, out of Yorkshire to see us, but like leeches to suck from us.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: We come compelled by want to crave our own.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Sir, for your own, than thus be satisfied,
Both hers and yours were left in trust with me,
And I will keep it for ye: must you appoint us,
Or what we please to like mixed with reproof,
You have been too saucy both, and you shall know,
I'll curb you for it, ask why; I'll have it so?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: We do but crave our own.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Your own sir: what's your own?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Our portions given us by our father's will,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Which here you spend.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Consume?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Ways worse than ill.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Nay, nay, nay, Will: prithee come away, we have a full gallon of sack stays in the fire for thee, thou must pledge it to the health of a friend of thine.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: What dost think these are Frank?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: They are fiddlers I think, if they be, I prithee send them into the next room, and let them scrape there, and we'll send to them presently.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p:
They are my brother's Frank, come out of Yorkshire, to the tavern here, to ask their portions:
they call my pleasures, riots, my company leproes, and like a school boy, they would tutor me?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: O, thou shouldst have done well to have bound them prentices when they were young, they would have made a couple of saucy tailors.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Tailors?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I birdlime: tailors: tailors are good men, and in the term time they wear good clothes. Come, you must learn more manners, stand at your brother's back, as to shift a Trencher neatly, and take a cup of sack, and a capon's leg contentedly.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: You are a slave
That feeds upon my brother like a fly,
Poisoning where thou dost suck.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: You lie.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: O, to my grief I speak it, you shall find,
There's no more difference in a tavern-haunter
Then is between a spittle and a beggar.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Thou workest on him like tempests on a ship.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: And he the worthy traffic that doth sink.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Thou mak'st his name more loathsome than a grave.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Livest like a dog, by vomit,

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Die a slave?

div.stage: Here they draw. Wentlo, and Bartley come in, and the two vintner's boys, with clubs. All set upon the two brothers. Butler, scarborrows man comes in, stands by, sees them fight takes part with neither.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p:
Do, fight: I love you all well, because you were my old master's sons, but I'll neither part you, nor be partaker with you. I come to bring my mast, news, he hath two sons born at a birth in Yorkshire, and I find him together by the ears with his brothers in a tavern in London. Brother and brother at odds, 'tis naught: sure, it was not thus in the days of charity. What's this world like to? Faith just like an innkeepers chamber-pot, receives all waters, good and bad, it had need of much scouring. My old mast kept a good house, and twenty or thirty tall sword and buckler men about him, and y faith his son differs not much, he will have mettle to, though he hath not store of cutler's blades, he will have plenty of vintner's pots. His father kept a good house for honest men,
his tenants, that brought him in part, and his son keeps a bad de house with knaves that help to consume all. 'tis but the change of time: why should any man repine at it: Crekits, good living, and lucky worms, were wont to feed, sing, and rejoice in the father's chimney, and now carrion crows builds in the son's kitchen, I could be sorry for it, but I am too old to weep. Well then, I will go tell him news of his offsprings.

div.stage: Enter the two brothers, Thomas and John Scarborrow hurt, and sister.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Alas good brothers, how came this mischance?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Our portions, our brother hath given us our portions sister, hath he not?

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: He would not be so monstrous I am sure.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Excuse him not, he is more degenerate,
Then greedy vipers that devour their mother,
They eat on her but to preserve themselves,
And he consumes himself, and beggars us.
A tavern is his inn, where amongst slaves,
He kills his substance, making pots the graves
To bury that which our forefathers gave.
I asked him for our portions, told him that you
Were brought to London, and we were in want,
Humbly we craved our own, when his reply
Was, he knew none we had, beg, starve, or die.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.l: Alas what course is left for us to live by then?

sp.speaker: Tho
sp.l: In troth sister, we two to beg in the fields,
And you to betake yourself to the old trade,
Filling of small cans in the suburbs.

sp.speaker: Sist
sp.l: Shall I be left then like a common road,
That every beast that can but pay his toll
May travel over, and like to cammomil,
Flourish the better being trodden on.

sp.speaker: But,
sp.p: Well I will not curse him: he seedes now upon sack and anchoves with a pox to him: but if he be not fain before he dies to eat acorns, let me live with nothing but pollarded, and my mouth be made a cooking stool for every scold to set her tail on.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: How now butler, what's the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p:
Your brother means to lame as many as he can, that
is a beggar himself, many live with him in the hospital. His wife sent me out of Yorkshire, to tell him, that God had blessed him with two sons, he bids a plague of them, a vengeance of her, crosses me o'er the pate, and sends me to the surgeons to seek salve: I looked at least he should have given me a brace of angels for my pains.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Thou hast not lost all thy longing, I am sure he hath given thee a cracked crown.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: A plague on his fingers, I cannot tell, he is your brother and my master, I would be loath to prophesy of him, but whosoe'er doth curse his children being infants, ban his wife lying in childbed, and beats his man brings him news of it, they may be born rich, but they shall live slaves, be knaves, and die beggars.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Did he do so.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Guess you, he bid a plague of them, a vengeance on her, and sent me to the surgeons.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.l: Why then I see there is no hope of him. Some husbands are respectless of their wives,
During the time that they are useless,
But none with infants blessed, can nourish hate,
But love the mother for the children's sake.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: But he that is given over unto sin,
Leprosed therewith without, and so within,
Oh butler, we were issue to one father?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: And he was an honest gentleman.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Whose hopes were better than the sun he left,
Should set so soon, unto his house's shame.
He lives in taverns, spending of his wealth,
And here his brothers and distressed sister,
Not having any means to help us with.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Not a Scots baubee (By this hand) to bless us with.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: And not content to riot out his own,
But he detains our portions: suffers us
In this strange air, open to every wrack,
Whilst he in riot swims to be in lack.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: The moors the pity.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.l: I know not what course to take me to,
Honesty fain would live: what shall I do?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Sooth I'll tell you, your brother hath hurt us,
We three will hurt you, and then go all to a spittle together.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.l: Jest not at her, whose burden is too grievous,
But rather lend a means how to relieve us.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Well I do pity you, and the rather because you sale, you would fain live honest and want means for it, for I can tell you 'tis as strange here to see a maid fair, poor, and honest, as to see a collier with a clean face. Maids here do live (Especially without maintenance)
sp.l: Like mice going to a trap,
They nibble long ▪ at last they get a clap.
sp.p: Your father was my good benefactor, and gave me a house whilst I live to put my head in: for I would be loath then to see his only daughter, for want of means, turn punk, I have a drift to keep you honest. Have you a care to keep yourself so, yet you shall not know of it, for women's tongues are like sieves, they will hold nothing, they have power to vent. You two will further me ▪

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: In any thing good honest butler.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: If't be to take a purse I'll be one.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Perhaps thou speakest righter than thou art aware of: well, as chance it, I have received my wages: there is forty shillings for you, I'll set you in a lodging, and till you hear from us, let that provide for you, we'll first to the surgeons,
sp.l: To keep you honest, and to keep you brave,
For once an honest man, will turn a knave.

div.stage: Enter Scarborrow having a boy carrying a torch with him, Ilford Wentlo, and barley.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Boy ▪ bear the torch fair: now am I armed to fight with a windmill, and to take the wall of an emperor: much drink, no money: a heavy head, and a light pair of heels.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: O, stand man?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I wear an excellent creature to make a punk of, I should down with the least touch of a knave's finger, thou hast made a good night of this: what hast won Frank?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: A matter of nothing, some hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p:
This is the hell of all gamesters ▪ I think when they are at play, the board eases up the money: for if there be five hundred pound lost, there's never but a hundred pounds won. Boy, take
the wall of any man, and yet by light, such deeds of darkness may not be.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: What dost mean by that will?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: To save charge, and walk like a fury with a firebrand in my hand, every one goes by the light, and we'll go by the smoke.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Boy, keep the wall: I will not budge for any man, by these thumbs, and the paring of the nails shall stick in thy teeth not for a world.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Who's this, young Scarborrow?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: The man that the mare rid on.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Is this the reverence that you owe to me?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: You should have brought me up better.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: That vice should thus transform man to a beast.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Go to, your name's lord, I'll talk with you when your out a debt and ha' better clothes.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: I pity thee even with my very soul.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Pity ith' thy throat, I can drink muscadine and eggs, and mulled sack, do you hear: you put a piece of turned stuff upon me, but I will -

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: What will you do sir?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Piss in thy way, and that's no slander.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Your sober blood will teach you otherwise.

sp.speaker: S. Will.
sp.p: My honoured lord, you're happily well met,

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.l: Ill met to see your nephew in this case,
More like a brute beast, than a gentleman.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.l: Fi: nephew, shame you not thus to transform yourself?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Can your nose smell a torch.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
