sp.l: Be not so wild, it is thine uncle Scarborrow.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Why then 'tis the more likely 'tis my father's brother.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.l: Shame to our name, to make thyself a beast,
Thy body worthy born, and thy youth's breast
Tiled in due time for better discipline.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Thyself new married to a noble house,
Rich in possessions, and posterity,
Which should call home thy unstaid affections.

sp.speaker: S. Will.
sp.l: Where thou mak'st havoc.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Riot, spoil, and waste,

sp.speaker: Sir Willi ▪
sp.l: Of what thy father left.

sp.speaker: Lor.
sp.l: And livest disgraced.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I'll send you shorter to heaven, than you came to the earth, do you catechise? Do you catechise?

div.stage: He draws and strikes at them.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Hold, hold, do you draw upon your uncle?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Pox of that lord,
We'll meet at mitre, where we'll sup down sorrow,
We are drunk tonight , and so we'll be tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Why now I see: what I hard of, I believed not,
Your kinsman lives.

sp.speaker: S. Wil.
sp.p: Like to a swine.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: A perfect epithet he feeds on draff,
And wallows in the mire, to make men laugh,
I pity him.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.l: No pities fit for him.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Yet we'll advise him.

sp.speaker: Sir william
sp.l: He is my kinsman.

sp.speaker: Lord
sp.l: Being in the pit where many do fall in,
We will both comfort him, and counsel him.

div.stage: Anoyse within, crying, follow, follow, follow: then enter Butler, Thomas and John Scarborrow with money bags.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: What shall we do now butler?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: A man had better line a good handsome pair of gallows before his time, then be born to do these sucklings good, their mother's milk not wrung out of their nose yet, they know no more how to behave themselves in this honest and needful calling of purse-taking, than I do to piece stockings.

div.stage: Within. This way, this way, this way.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: 'Sfoot what shall we do now?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: See if they do not quake like a trembling. Asp-leaf, and look more miserable than one of the wicked elders pictured in the painted cloth, should they but come to the credit to be arraigned for their valour, before a worshipful bench, their very looks would hang 'em, and they were indicted but for stealing of eggs.

div.stage: Within. Follow, follow, this way follow.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Butler.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Honest butler.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p:
Squat heart squat, creep me into these bushes,
lie me as close to the ground as you would do to a wench.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: How good butler, show us how.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: By the moon patroness of all purse-takers, who would be troubled with such changelings, squat heart squat.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Thus butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: I so suckling, so, stir not now, if the peering rogues chance to go over you, yet stir not younger brothers call you 'em and have no more forecast, I am ashamed of you, these are such whose fathers had need leave them money, even to make them ready withal, for by this hilts, they have not wit to button their sleeves without teaching, close, squat close. Now if the lot of hanging do fall to my share, so, than the father's old man drops for his young masters. If it chance it chances and when it chances, heaven and the sheriff send me a good rope, I would not go up the lather twice for any thing, in the mean time preventions, honest preventions do well, off with my skin, so you on the ground, and I to this tree to escape the gallows.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Do follow, if I do not deceive you, I'll bid a pox of this wit, and hang with a good grace.

div.stage: Enter sir John Harcop with two or three other with him.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Up to this wood they took, search near my friends, I am this morn robbed of three hundred pound.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: I am sorry there was not four to have made even money now by the devil's horns, 'tis sir John Harcop.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Leave not a bush unbare, nor tree unsearched, as sure as I was robbed the thieves went this way.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Theirs nobody I perceive but may lie at sometime for one of them climbed this ways.
1. Stand, I hear a voice, and here's an owl in an ivy bush.

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.p: You lie, 'tis an old servingman in a nut-tree.
2 sirrah, sir, what make you in that tree.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Gathering of nuts, that such fools as you are may crack the shells, and I eat the kernels.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: What fellows that?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Sir John Harcop, my noble knight, I am glad of your good health, you hear your age fair, you keep a good house, I ha' fed at your board, and been drunk in your buttery.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: But sirrah: what made you in that tree?
My man and I at foot of yonder hill
Were by three knaves robbed of three hundred pound.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: A shrewd loss by’r lady sir, but your good worship may now see the fruit of being miserable: you will ride but with one man to save horse-meat and man's meat at your inn at night, and lose three hundred pound in a morning.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Sirrah, I say I ha' lost three hundred pound.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: And I say sir, I wish all miserable knights might be served so: for had you kept half a dozen tall fellows, as a man of your coat should do, they would have helped now to keep your money.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: But tell me sir, why lurked you in that tree?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Marry, I will tell you sir, coming to the top of the hill where you (Right worshipful) were robbed at the bottom, and seeing some a scuffling together, my mind straight gave me there were knaves abroad. Now sir, I knowing myself to be old, tough, and unwieldy, not being able to do as I would, as much as to say ▪ rescue you (Right worshipful,) I like an honest man, one of the King's liege people, and a good subject

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.p: 'A says well sir.

Got me up to the top of that tree: the tree (If it could speak) would bear me witness, that there I might see which way the knaves took, then to tell you of it, and you right worshipfully to send hue to cry after 'em.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Was it so.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Nay 'twas so sir.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Nay then I tell thee they took into this wood.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: And I tell thee (Setting thy worsh. knighthood aside) he lies in his throat that says so: had not one of them a white frock? Did they not bind your worship's knighthood by the thumbs? then faggoted you and the fool your man, back to back.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: He says true.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Why then so truly, came not they into this wood, but took over the lawns, and left Winno steeple on the left hand.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: It may be so, by this they are out of reach, well, farewell it.

sp.speaker: But,
sp.p: Ride with more men, good knight.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: It shall teach me wit.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: So, if this be not played a weapon beyond a scholar's prize, let me be hissed at. Now to the next. Come out you hedgehogs?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: O butler, thou deservest to be chronicled for this.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Do not bely me, if I had my right I deserve to be hanged fort. But come, down with your dust, our morning's purchase.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Here 'tis, thou hast played well, thou deservest two shares in it.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Three hundred pound: a pretty breakfast: many a man works harden all his days and never sees half the money. But come, though it be badly got, it shall be better bestowed. But do ye hear galants, I ha' not taught you this trade to get your livings by. Use it not, for if you do, though I scaped by the nut tree, be sure you'll speed by the rope: but for your pains at this time, there's a hundred pounds for you, how you shall bestow it, I'll give you instructions. But do you hear, look you go not to your gills, your punks, and your cock-tricks with it, if I hear you do: as I am an honest thief, though I helped you now out of the briers, I'll be a means yet to help you to the gallows. How the rest shall be employed I have determined, and by the way I'll make you acquainted with it.
sp.l: To steal is bad, but taken where is store,
The faults the less, being done to help the poor

div.stage: Enter Ilford, wentloe, Bartley. Ilford having a letter in his hand.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Sure I ha' said my prayers, and lived virtuously a late, that this good fortunes befallen me. Look gallants: I am sent for to come down to my father's burial.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: But dust mean to go?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Troth no, I'll go down to take possession of his land, let the country bury him and the will: I'll stay here a while, to save charge at his funeral.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: And how dost feel thyself Frank, now thy father is dead?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: As I did before, with my hands, how should I feel myself else? But I'll tell you news gallants.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: What's that? Dost mean now to serve God?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Faith partly, for I intend shortly to go to church, and from thence do faithful service to one woman.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Good, I ha' met my flesh-hooks together.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: What, dost mean to be married?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I mongrel, married.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: That's a bait for me.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I will now be honestly married.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Its impossible, for thou hast been a whoremaster this seven year.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter, I will now marry, and to some honest woman to, and so from hence her virtues shall be a countenance to my vices.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: What shall she be, prithee?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: No lady, no widow, nor no waiting gentlewoman, for under protection
Ladies may lord their husband's heads, widows will woodcocks make, and chambermaids of serving-men learn that, they'll ne'er forsake.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Who wilt thou wed then, prithee?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: To any maid, so she be fair: to any maid, so she be rich to any maid so she be young: and to any maid

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: So she be honest.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Faith, it's no great matter for her honesty, for in these days, that's a dowry out of request.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: From these crabs will I gather sweetness: wherein I'll imitate the bee, that sucks her honey, not from the sweetest flowers, but timb the bitterest: so these having been the means to beggar my master, shall be the helps to relieve his brothers and sister.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: To whom shall I now be a suitor?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Fair fall ye gallants.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Nay, and she be fair she shall fall sure enough. Butler, how is't good butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Will you be made gallants?

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Ay, but not willingly cuckolds, though we are now talking about wives.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Let your wives agree of that after, will you first be richly married?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: How Butler: richly married?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Rich in beauty, rich in purse, rich in virtue, rich in all things. But mum, I'll say nothing, I know of two or three rich heirs. But Cargo, my fiddlestick cannot play without resin: avant.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Butler.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Dost not know me butler?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: For kex, dried kex, that in summer ha' been so liberal to fodder other men's cattle, and scarce have enough to keep your own in winter. Mine are precious cabinets, and must have precious jewels put into them, and I know you to he merchants of stockfish, and not men for my market: then vanish.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Come, ye old madcap you, what need all this? Cannot a man ha' been a little whore-master in his youth, but you must upbraid him with it, and tell him of his defects, which when he is married, his wife shall find in him? Why my father's dead man now, who by his death has left me the better part of a thousand a year.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Tut, she of Lancashire has fifteen hundred.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Let me have her then, good butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: And then she the bright beauty of Leicestershipre, has a thousand, nay thirteen hundred a year, at least.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Or let me have her, honest butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Besides, she the most delicate, sweet countenanced, black browed gentlewoman in Northamptonshire, in substance equals the best of 'em.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Let me have her then.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: Or I.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Or I, good butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: You were best play the parts of right fools, and most desperate whoremasters, and go together by the ears for them ere ye see them. But they are the most rare featured, well faced, excellent spoke, rare qualitied, virtuous, and worthy to be admired gentlewoman,

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: And rich butler?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: (I that must be one, though they want all the rest) and rich gallants, as are from the utmost parts of Asya, to these present confines of Europe.

sp.speaker: All
sp.p: And wilt thou help us to them butler?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p:
Faith, 'tis to be doubted, for precious pearl will hardly be bought without precious stones, and I think there's scarce one indifferent one to be found, betwixt you three: yet since there is some hope ye may prove honest, as by the death of your fathers.
Fathers you are proved rich, walk severally, for I knowing you all three to be covetous tug-muttons will not trust you with the sight of each others beauty but will severally, talk with you, and since you have deigned in this needful portion of wedlock to be ruled by me butler, will most bountifully provide wives for you generally.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Why that honestly said.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Why so, and now first to your sir knight

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Godamercy.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: You see this couple of abominable woodcocks hear.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: A pox on them, absolute coxcombs.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: You heard me tell them, I had intelligence to give of three gentlewomen.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Now indeed sit I ha' but the performance of one.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: And her I do intend for you, only for you.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Honest butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Now sir, she being but lately come to this town, and so nearly watched by the jealous eyes of her friends, she being a rich heir, lest she should be stolen away by some dissolute prodigal, or desperate estated spend thrift, as you ha' been sir.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: O but that's past butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: True I know't, and intend now but to make use of them, flatter with them with hopeful promises, and make them needful instruments.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: To help me to the wench,

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: You ha' hit it which thus must be effected, first by keeping close your purpose.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: Also concealing from them, the lodging beauty and riches of your new, but admirable mistress.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Of which your following happiness, if they should know either in envy of your good, or hope of their own advancement they'd make our labours known to the gentlewoman's uncles, and so our benefit be frustrate.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Admirable Butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Which done, all's but this, being as you shall be brought into her company, and by my praising your virtues you get possession of her love, one morning step to the tower, or to make all sure, hire some stipendiary priest for money: for money in these days, what will not be done, and what will not a man do for a rich wife, and with him make no more ado but marry hit in her lodging and being married, he with her and spare not.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Do they not see us, do they not see us, let me kiss thee, let me kiss thee butler, let but this be done, and all the benefit requital and happiness. I can promise thee fort, shall be this, I'll be thy rich master, and thou shalt carry my purse.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Enough, meet me at her lodging some half an hour hence: hark she lies.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I hate.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Fail not.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Will I live.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: I will but shift of these two rhinoceros,

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Wigens, Wingens, a couple of gulls.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: With some discourse of hope to wive them two, and be with you straight.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Blessed day, my love shall be thy cushion honest butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: So now to my tother gallants.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: O butler, we ha' been in passion at thy tediousness,

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Why look you. I had all this talk for your good.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Hadst.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: For you know the knight is but a scuruy-proud-prating-prodigall, licentious unnecessary.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: An ass, an ass, an ass.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Now you heard me tell him I had three wenches in store,

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: And he would ha' had them all would he.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Hear me, though he may live to be an ox, he had not now so much of the goat in him, but only hopes for one of the three when indeed I ha' but two, and knowing you to be men of more virtue, and dearer in my respect intend them to be yours.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: We shall honour thee.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: But how butler.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.p:
I am now going to their place of residence, situate in the choicest place in the city, and at the sign of the wolf just against gold-smiths-row
where you shall meet me, but ask not for me, only walk to and fro and to avoid suspicion you may spend some conference with the shopkeepers wives, they have seats built a purpose for such familiar entertainment, where from a bay window which is opposite, I will make you known to your desired beauties, commend the good parts you have.

sp.speaker: Went
sp.p: Byth' mass mine are very few.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: And win a kind of desire, as women are soon won to make you be beloved where you shall first kiss, than woe, at length wed, and at last bed my noble hearts.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: O butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Wenches bona robes, blessed beauties, without colour or counterfeit: away, put on you best clothes, get you to the barbers, curl up your hair, walk with the best struts you can, you shall see more at the window, and I ha' vowed to make you.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: Wilt thou.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Both fools, and I'll want of my wit but I'll do't.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: We will live together as fellows.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: As brothers.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: As arrant knaves if I keep you company,
Oh, the most wretched season of this time,
These men like fish, do swim within one stream,
Yet they'd eat one another, making no conscience
To drink with them they'd poison, no offence,
Betwixt their thoughts and actions have control,
But headlong run, like an unbiased bowl,
Yet I will throw them on, but like to him,
At play knows how to lose, and when to win.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: O, are you come. And fit as I appointed: so, 'tis well, you know you cues, and have instructions how to bear yourselves: all, all is fit, play but your part, your states from hence are firm.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: What shall I term this creature not a man.
sp.stage: Betwixt this Butler leads Ilford in.
sp.l: He's not of mortals temper but he's one,
Made all of goodness, though of flesh and bone,
Oh brother, brother, but for that honest man,
As near to misery had been our breath,
As where the thundering pellet strikes is death.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Ay, my shift of shirts and change of clothes know't.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Well tell of him, like bells whose music rings
One coronation day for joy of Kings,
That hath preserved their steeples not like tolls,
That summons living tears for the dead souls,

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: God's precious sir, the hell sir, even as you had new kissed, and were about to court her, if her uncles be not come.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: A plague on thee, spit out.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: But 'tis no matter sir, stay you here in this upper chamber, and I'll stay beneath with her, 'tis ten to one you shall hear them talk now, of the greatness of her possessions, the care they have to see her well bestowed, the admirableness of her virtues, all which for all their coming, shall be but happiness ordained for you, and by my means be your inheritance.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Then thou'lt shift them away, and keep from the sight of them.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Have I not promised to make you.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Thou hast.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Go to then, rest here with patience, and be confident in my trust, only in my absence, you may praise God for the blessedness you have to come, and say your prayers if you will, I'll but prepare her heart for entertainment of your love, dismiss them, for your free access, and return straight.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Honest-blest-natural-friend, thou dealest with me like a brother: butler,Exit.sure heaven hath reserved this man to wear grey-hairs to do me good, now will I listen, listen close, and suck in her uncle's words with a rejoicing ear,

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: As we were saying brother,
Where shall we find a husband for my niece.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Marry she shall find one here though you little know't, thanks,
thanks honest butler.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: She is left rich in money, plate, and jewels.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Comfort, comfort to my soul.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Hath all her manner houses richly furnished.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Good, good, I'll find employment for them.

sp.speaker: With. But.
sp.l: Speak loud enough that he may hear you.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I take her state to be about a thousand pound a year,

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: And that which my father, hath left me, will make it about fifteen, hundred admirable.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: Indebt to no man, then must our natural care be,
As she is wealthy to see her married well.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: And that she shall be as well as the priest can, he shall not,
Leave out a word on't.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I think she has.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: What a god's name.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: About four thousand pound in her great chest.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: And I'll find a vent fort I hope.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: She is virtuous, and she is fair.

sp.speaker: Ilf,
sp.l: And she were foul, being rich, I would be glad of her.

sp.speaker: But
sp.l: Pisht, pisht.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Come, we'll go visit her, but with this care,
That to no spendthrift we do marry her.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p:
You may chance be deceived old graybeards, ●eares he will spend some of it, thanks, thanks, honest butler, now do I see the happiness of my future estate, I walk me as tomorrow, being the day after my marriage, with my fourteen men in livery cloaks after me, and step to the wall in some chief street of the city, though I ha' no occasion to use it, that the shopkeepers may take notice how many followers stand bare to me, and yet in this latter age, the keeping of men being not in request, I will turn my aforesaid fourteen into two pages and two coaches, I will get myself into grace at court, run headlong into debt, and then look scurvily upon the city, I will walk you into the presence in the afternoon having put on a richer suit, than I wore in the morning, and call boy or sirrah, I will ha' the grace of some great lady though I pay fort, and at the next triumphs run a tilt, that when I run my course, though I break not my lance: she may whisper to herself, looking upon my smell, well run my knight
I will now keep great horses, scorning to have a quean to keep me, indeed I will practise all the gallantry in use, for by a wife comes all my happiness.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Now sir, you ha' heard her uncles, and how do you like them.

sp.speaker: Il.
sp.p: O but. they ha' made good thy words, and I am ravished with them.

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.p: And having seen and kissed the gentlewoman. how do you like her?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: O butler beyond discourse, she's paragon for a prince, than a fit implement for a gentleman, beyond my element.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Well then, since you like her, and by my means, she shall like you, nothing rests now but to have you married.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: True butler, but withal to have her portion.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Tut, that's sure yours when you are married once, for 'tis hers by inheritance, but do you love her?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: O, with my soul.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Ha you sworn as much.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: To thee, to her, and ha' called heaven to witness.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: How shall I know that.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Butler, here I protest, make vows irrevocable.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Upon your knees.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Upon my knees, with my heart, and soul I love her.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Will live with her.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Will live with her.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Marry her and maintain her.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Marry her and maintain her.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: For her forsake all other women.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Nay for her forswear all other women.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: In all degrees of love.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: In all degrees of love, either to court, kiss, give private favours, or use private means, I'll do nothing that married men being close whoremasters do, so I may have her.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: And yet you having been an open whoremaster, I will not believe you till I hear you swear as much in the way of contract to herself, and call me to be a witness.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: By heaven, by earth, by hell, by all that man can swear, I will so I may have her.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Enough.
Thus at first sight, rash men to women swear,
When such oaths broke, heaven grieves and sheds a tear:
But she's come, ply her, ply her.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Kind mistress, as I protested, so again I vow, i'faith I love you.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.l: And I am not sir so uncharitable,
To hate the man that loves me.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Love me then,
The which loves you as angels loves good men,
Who wish them to live with them ever,
In that high bliss whom hell cannot diss ever.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: I'll steal away and leave them, so wise men do,
Whom they would match, let them ha' leave to woe.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Mistress I know your worth is beyond my desert, yet by my praising of your virtues, I would not have you as women use to do, become proud.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: None of my affections are pride's children, nor a kin to them

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Can you love me them?

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: I can, for I love all the world, but am in love with none.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Yet be in love with me, let your affections
Combine with mine, and let our souls
Like turtles have a mutual sympathy,
Who love so well, that they together die,
Such is my life, who covets to expire,
If it should lose your love.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.l: May I believe you?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Introth you may,
Your life's my life, your death my dying day.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Sir the commendations I have received from butler of your birth and worth, together with the judgement of mine own eye, bids me believe and love you.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: O seal it with a kiss,
Blessed hour my life had never joy till this.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: Here about is the house sure.

sp.speaker: Wentlo.
sp.p: We cannot mistake it, for here's the sign of the wolf and the bay-window.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: What so close? 'tis well, I ha' shifted away your uncle's mistress, but see the spite sir Francis, if you same couple of smell-smocks, Wentloe and Bartley, ha' not scented after us.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: A pox on 'em, what shall we do then butler?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: What but be married straight man.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I but how butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Tut, I never fail at a dead lift, for to perfect your bliss, I have provided you a priest.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Where, prithee butler where?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Where? But beneath in her chamber. I ha' filled his hands with coin, and he shall tie you fast with words, he shall close your hands in one, and then do clap yourself into her sheets and spare not.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: O sweet.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Down, down, 'tis the only way for you to get up.
Thus in this task, for others good I toil,
And she kind gentlewoman weds herself,
Having been scarcely wooed, and ere her thoughts,
Have learned to love him, that being her husband,
She may relieve her, brothers in their wants,
She marries him to help her nearest kin,
I make the match, and hope it is no sin.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: 'Sfoot it is scurvy walking, for us so near the two counters, would he would come once?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Mass he's yonder: now butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: O gallants are you here, I ha' done wonders for you commended you to the gentlewomen, who having taken note of your good legs, and good faces, have a liking to you, meet me beneath.

sp.speaker: Both
sp.p: Happy butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: They are yours, and you are theirs, meet me beneath I say.
By this they are wed, I and perhaps have bedded,
Now follows whether knowing she is poor,
He'll swear he loved her as he swore before.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Ho sirrah, who would ha' thought it, I perceive now a woman may be a maid, be married, and lose her maidenhead, and all in half and an hour, and how dost like me now wench.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.l: As doth befit your servant and your wife,
That owe you love and duty all my life.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: And there shall be no love lost, nor service neither, I'll do thee service at board, and thou shalt do me service a-bed : now must I as young married men use to do, kiss my portion out of my young wife. Thou art my sweet rogue, my lamb, my pigsny, my playfellow, my pretty pretty any thing, come a buss prithee, so 'tis my kind heart, and what's thou what now?

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Not till you tell me sir,

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: I ha' got thee with child in my conscience, and like a kind husband, methinks I breed it for thee. For I am already sick at my stomach and long extremely. Now must thou be my helpful physician, and provide for me.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.l: Even to my blood,
What's mine is yours, to gain your peace or good.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: What a kind soul is this, could a man have found a greater content in a wife, if he should ha' sought through the world for her: prithee heart as I said, I long, and in good troth I do, and methinks thy first child will be born without a nose, if I lose my longing, 'tis but for a trifle too, yet methinks it will do me no good unless thou effect it for me. I could take thy keys myself, go into thy closet, and read over the deeds and evidences of thy land, and in reading over them, rejoice I had such blessed fortune to have so fair a wife with so much endowment, and then open thy chests, and survey thy plate, jewels, treasure. But a pox on't, all will do me no good, unless thou effect it for me.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.l: Sir I will show you all the wealth I have,
Of coin, of jewels, or possessions,

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Good gentle heart, I'll give thee another buss for that, for that give thee a new gown tomorrow morning, by this hand do thou but dream what stuff and what fashion thou wilt have it on tonight .

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.l: The land I can endow you with, is my love,
The riches I possess for you is love,
A treasure greater than is land or gold,
It cannot be forfeited, and it shall ne'er be sold.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p:
Love I know that, and I'll answer thee love for. Love in abundance: but come prithee come, let's see these deeds and evidences,
this money, plate, and jewels, with ha' thy child born without a nose ▪ if thou beest so careless, spare not, why my little frappet you, I heard thy uncle's talk of thy riches, that thou hadst hundreds a year, several lordships, manors houles, thousands of pounds in your great chests, jewels, plate, and rings in your little box.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: And for that riches you did marry me.

sp.speaker: Ilf
sp.p: Troth I did, as now adays bachelors do sware I loved thee but indeed married thee for thy wealth.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.l: Sir I beseech you say not your oaths were such,
So like false coin, being put unto the touch,
Who bear a flourish in the outward show,
Of a true stamp, but truly are not so,
You swore me love, I gave the like to you,
Then as a ship being wedded to the sea,
Does either sail or sink even so must I,
You being the haven to which my hopes must she.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: True chuck I am thy haven, and harbour too,
And like a ship I took thee, who brings home treasure
As thou to me, the merchant-venturer.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.l: What riches I am ballast with are yours.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: That's kindly said now,

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.l: If but with sand, as I am but with earth,
Being your right of right, you must receive me,
I ha' no other lading but my love.
Which in abundance I will render you,
If other fraught you do expect my store,
I'll pay you ●eares, my riches, are no more.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: How's this? how's this? I hope you do but jest,

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.l: I am sister to decayed Scarborrow.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.l: Whose substance your enticements did consume.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: Worse than an ague.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.l: Which as you did believe so they supposed,
'Twas fitter for yourself then for another,
To keep the sister, had undone the brother.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p:
I am gulled by this hand. An old Co●ichacher, and beguiled; where the pox now are my two coaches, choice of houses, several
suits, a plague on them, and I know not what: do you hear puppet, do you think you shall not be damned for this, to cozen a gentleman of his hopes, and compel yourself into matrimony with a man, whether he will or no with you, I ha' made a fair match i'faith, will any man buy my commodity out of my hand, as God save me he shall have her for half the money she cost me.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: O, ha we met you sir.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: What, turned mitcher, steal a wife, and not make your old friends acquainted with it.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: A pox on her, I would you had her.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Well, God give you joy, we can hear of your good fortune, now 'tis done, though we could not be acquainted with it aforehand.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: As that you have two thousand pound a year.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Two or three manor houses.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: A wife, fair, rich, and virtuous.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Pretty in faith, very pretty.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Store of gold.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: Plate in abundance.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Better, better, better.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: And so many oxen, that their horns are able to store all the cuckolds in your country.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Do not make me mad good gentlemen, do not make me mad, I could be made a cuckold with more patience, then endure this.

sp.speaker: We.
sp.p: For we shall have you turn proud now, grow respectless of your ancient acquaintance, why butler told us of it: who was the maker of the match for you?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: A pox of his furtherance, gentlemen as you are Christians, vex me no more, that I am married I confess, a plague of the fates, that wedding and hanging comes by destiny, but for the riches she has brought, bear witness how I'll reward her.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Whore, I and jade, witch, ill-faced, stinking-breath, crooked-nose, worse than the devil, and a plague on thee that ever I saw thee.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: A comedy, a comedy.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: What's the meaning of all this, is this the mask after thy marriage.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: O gentlemen, I am undone, I am undone, for I am married, I that could not abide a woman, but to make her a whore, hated all she-creatures, fair and poor, swore I would never marry but to one that was rich, and to be thus coney-catched . Who do you think this is gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Why your wife, who should it be else?

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: That's my misfortune, that marrying her in hope she was rich, she proves to be the beggarly sister to the more beggarly Scarborrow.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Ay, you may laugh, but she shall cry as well as I for't,

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: Nay, do not weep.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: He does but counterfeit now to delude us, he has all her portion of land, coin, plate, jewels: and now dissembles thus lest we should borrow some money of him.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: And you be kind gentlemen lend me some, for having paid the priest, I ha' not so much left in the world, as will higher me a horse to carry me away from her.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: But art thou thus gulled in faith.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Are you sure you ha' eyes in your head.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: Why then, by her brother's setting one in my conscience, who knowing thee now to ha' somewhat to take to, by the death of thy father, and that he hath spent her portion, and his own possessions, hath laid this plot, for thee to marry her, and so he to be rid of her himself.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Nay, that's without question, but I'll be revenged of 'em both, for you minx. Nay 'sfoot, give 'em me, or I'll kick else.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Good, sweet.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Sweet with a pox, you stink in my nose, give me your jewels? Nay bracelets too.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: O me, most miserable.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Out of my sight, I and out of my doors, for now, what's within this house is mine, and for your brother
sp.l: He made this match, in hope to do you good,
And I wear this for which, shall draw his blood.

sp.speaker: Went.
sp.p: A brave resolution.

sp.speaker: Bart.
sp.p: In which we'll second thee.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: Away, whore, out of my doors whore.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.l: O grief, that poverty should ha' that power to tear:
Men from themselves, though they wed, bed, and swear.

div.stage: Enter Thomas and John Scarborrow, with Butler.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: How now sister.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Undone, undone.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Why mistress, how is't? how is't?

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: My husband has forsook me.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: O perjury.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Has ta'ne my jewels, and my bracelets from me.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Vengeance, I played the thief for the money that bought 'em.

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.p: Left me distressed, and thirst me forth a doors.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Damnation on him, I will here no more,
But for his wrong revenge me on my brother,
Degenerate, and was the cause of all,
He spent our portion, and I'll see his fall.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.p: O but brother.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Persuade me not.
All hopes are shipwreck, misery comes on,
The comfort we did look from him is frustrate,
All means, all maintenance, but grief is gone.
And all shall end by his destruction.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: I'll follow and prevent, what in this heat may happen,
His want makes sharp his sword, to greates the ill,
If that one brother should another kill.

sp.speaker: But,
sp.l: And what will you do mistress?

sp.speaker: Sister
sp.l: I'll sit me down, sigh loud in stead of words,
And wound myself with grief as they with swords.
And for the sustenance that I should eat,
I'll feed on grief, 'tis woes best relished meat.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Good heart I pity you,
You shall not be so cruel to yourself,
I have the poor servingman's allowance,
Twelve pence a day to buy me sustenance,
One meal aday I'll eat, the tother fast,
To give your wants relief. And mistress
Be this some comfort to your miseries,
I'll ha' thin cheeks, ere you shall ha' wet eyes.
What is prodigality? Faith like a brush
That wears himself to flourish others clothes,
And having worn his heart even to the stump,
He's thrown away like a deformed lump.
O such am I, I ha' spent all the wealth
My ancestors did purchase, made others brave
In shape and riches, and myself a knave.
For though my wealth raised some to paint their door,
'Tis shut against me, saying I am but poor:
Nay, even the greatest arm, whose hand hath graced,
My presence to the eye of majesty, shrinks back,
His fingers clutch, and like to lead,
They are heavy to raise up my state, being dead.
By which I find, spend thrifts, and such am I,
Like strumpets flourish, but are foul within,
And they like snakes, know when to cast their skin.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Turn, draw, and die, I come to kill thee.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: What's he that speaks? Like sickness: o is't you,
Sleep still, you cannot move me, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Think not my fury slakes so, or my blood
Can cool itself to temper by refusal,
Turn or thou diest.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I do not wish to kill thee like a slave,
That taps men in their cups, and broach their hearts,
Ear with a warning piece they have waked their ears,
I would not like to powder shoot thee down,
To a flat grave, ere thou hast thought to frown:
I am no coward, but in manly terms,
And fairest oppositions vow to kill thee.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: From whence proceeds this heat.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: From sparkles bred by thee, that like a villain.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Ha.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I'll hallow it in thine ears till thy soul quake to hear it,
That like a villain hast undone thy brothers.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Would thou wert not so near me: yet farewell.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: By nature, and her laws make us a kin,
as near as are these hands, or sin to sin.
Draw and defend thyself, or I'll forget
Thou art a man.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Would thou were not my brother?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I disclaim them.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Are we not offspring of one parent wretch.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I do forget it, pardon me the dead,
I should deny the pains you bid for me.
My blood grows hot for vengeance, thou hast spent
My life's revenues that our parents purchased.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: O do not wrack me with remembrance on't.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Thou hast made my life a beggar in this world,
And I will make thee bankrupt of thy breath:
Thou hast been so bad, the best I can give,
Thou art a devil, not with men to live.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Then take a devil's payment.

div.stage: Here they make a pass one upon another, when at Scarborrowes back. comes in Ilford, Wentloe, and Bartley.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.p: He's here, draw gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Went. Bart.
sp.p: Die Scarborrow.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Girt round with death.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: How set upon by three, 'sfoot fear not brother, yond cowards, three to one, slaves, worse than fencers that wear long weapons. You shall be fought withal, you shall be fought withal.

div.stage: Here the brothers join, drive the rest out, and return.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Brother I thank you, for you now have been
A patron of my life, forget the sin
I pray you, with my loose and wasteful hours,
Hath made against your fortunes, I repent 'em,
And wish I could new joint and strength your hopes,
Though with indifferent ruin of mine own.
I have a many sins, the thought of which
Like finished needles prick me to the soul,
But find your wrongs, to have the sharpest point.
If penitence your losses might repair,
You should be rich in wealth, and I in care.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I do believe you sir, but I must tell you,
evils the which are 'gainst another done,
Repentance makes no satisfaction
To him that feels the smart. Our father sir,
Left in your trust my portion: you ha' spent it,
And suffered me (Whilst you in riots house,
A drunken tavern, spilt my maintenance
Perhaps upon the ground with overflown cups,
Like birds in hardest winter half starved, to fly)
And pick up any food, lest I should die.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: I prithee let us be at peace together.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: At peace for what? For spending my inheritance,
By yonder son that every soul has life by,
As sure as thou hast life I'll fight with thee.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: I'd not be moved unto't.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I'll kill thee then, wert thou now clasped
Within thy mother, wife, or children's arms.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Wouldst homicide? art so degenerate?
Then let my blood grow hot.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: For it shall cool.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: To kill rather than be killed is manhoods rule.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Stay let not your wraths meet.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Heart, what mak'st thou here?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Say who are you, or you, are you not one,
That scarce can make a fit distinction
Betwixt each other. Are you not brothers?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I renounce him.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Shalt not need.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Give way.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Have at thee,

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Who stirs, which of you both hath strength within his arm
To wound his own breast, whose so desperate,
To dam himself by killing of himself,
Are you not both one flesh?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Heart, give me way.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Be not a bar betwixt us, or by my sword
I'll mete thy grave out.

sp.speaker: Joh.
sp.l: O do, for god's sake do?
'tis happy death, if I may die and you
Not murder one another. O do but harken,
When dus the sun and moon born in one frame
Contend, but they breed earthquakes in men's hearts:
When any star prodigiously appears,
Tells it not fall of Kings or fatal years.
And then if brother's fight, what may men think,
Sin grows so high, 'tis time the world should sink.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: My heart grows cool again, I wish it not.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Stop not my fury, or by my life I swear,
I will reveal the robbery we ha' done,
And take revenge on thee,
That hinders me to take revenge on him.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: I yield to that, but ne'er consent to this,
I shall then die as mine own, sin affords,
Fall by the law, not by my brother's swords.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Then by that light that guides me here I vow,
I'll straight to sir John Harcop, and make known
We were the two that robbed him.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Prithee do.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Sin has his shame, and thou shalt ha' thy due.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.l: Thus have I shown the nature of a brother,
Though you have proved unnatural to me.
He's gone in heat to publish out the theft,
Which want and your unkindness forest us to,
If now I die that death and public shame,
Is a corrosive to your soul, blot to your name.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: O 'tis too true, there's not a thought I think,
But must partake thy griefs, and drink
A relish of thy sorrow and misfortune,
With weight of others tears I am o'er born,
That scarce am Atlas to hold up mine own,
And all too good for me. A happy creature
In my cradle, and have made myself
The common curse of mankind by my life,
Undone my brothers, made them thieves for bread,
And begotten pretty children to live beggars,
Oh conscience, how thou are stung to think upon't,
my brothers unto shame must yield their blood,
My babes at others stirrups beg their food,
Or else turn thieves to, and be choked fort,
Die a dog's death, be perched upon a tree,
Hang betwixt heaven and earth, as fit for neither,
The curse of heaven that's due to reprobates,
Descends upon my brothers, and my children,
And I am parent to it, ay, I am parent to it.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Where are you sir?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: Why starest thou, what's thy haste?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Here's fellows swarm like flies to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: What are they?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Snakes I think sir, for they come with stings in their mouths, and their tongues are turned to teeth to: they claw villanously, they have eat up your honest name, and honourable reputation by railing against you, and now they come to devour your possessions.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: In plainer energy, what are they, speak?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Mantichoras, monstrous beasts, enemies to mankind, that ha' double rows of teeth in their mouths. They are usurers, they come yawning for money, and the sheriff with them, is come to serve an extent upon you land, and then cease on your body by force of execution, they ha' begirt the house round.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: So that the roof our ancestors did build
For their son's comfort, and their wives for charity,
I dare not to look out.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Besides sir, here's your poor children.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Poor children they are indeed.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: Come with fire and water: tears in their eyes, and burning grief in their hearts, and desire to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Heap sorrow upon sorrow? Tell me, are
My brothers gone to execution?
For what I did, for every heinous sin,
Sits on his soul by whom it did begin.
And so did theirs by me. Tell me withal,
My children carry moisture in their eyes,
Whose speaking drops, say father, thus must we
ask our relief, or die with infamy,
For you ha' made us beggars. Yet when thy tale has killed me
To give my passage comfort from this stage,
Say all was done by enforced marriage:
My grave will then be welcome.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: What shall we do sir?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Do as the devil does, hate panther-mankind,
And yet I lie: for devil's sinners love,
When men hate men, though good like some above.

div.stage: Enter Scarborrowes wife Katherine with two children.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Your wife's come in sir.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Thou liest, I ha' not a wife. None can be called,
True man and wife, but those whom heaven installed. Say,

sp.speaker: Kath.
sp.l: O my dear husband?

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: You are very welcome, peace: we'll ha' compliment.
Who are you gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Sir your distressed wife, and these your children.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Mine? Where, how begotten:
Prove me by certain instance that's divine,
That I should call them lawful, or the mine.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: Were we not married sir?

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: No, though we heard the words of ceremony,
But had hands knit as felons that wear fetters
Forced upon them. For tell me woman,
Did ere my love with sighs entreat thee mine,
Did ever I in willing conference,
Speak words, made half with tears that I did love thee.
Or was I ever
But glad to see thee as all lovers are.
No, no, thou knowest I was not.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: O me.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: The moors the pity.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: But when I came to church, I did there stand
All water, whose forest breach had drowned my land,
Are you my wife, or these my children?
Why 'tis impossible, for like the skies,
Without the sun's light, so look all your eyes,
Dark, cloudy, thick, and full of heaviness,
within my country there was hope to see
Me and my issue to be like our fathers,
Upholders of our country, all our life,
Which should ha' been, if I had wed a wife.
Where now,
As dropping leaves in autumn you look all,
And I that should uphold you like to fall,

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: 'Twas, nor, shall be my fault. Heaven bear me witness.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Thou liest? strumpet thou liest?

sp.speaker: Bu.
sp.l: O sir.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Peace saucy Jack, strumpet I say thou liest,
For wife of mine thou art not, and these thy bastards
Whom I begotten of thee, with this unrest,
That bastards born, are born not to be blessed

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: One me pour all your wrath, but not on them.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: On thee, and them, for 'tis the end of lust,
To scourge itself, heaven lingering to be just:
Harlot.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Husband.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Bastardes.

sp.speaker: Child.
sp.l: Father.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: What heart not pities this?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Even in your cradle, you were accursed of heaven,
Thou an adulteress in thy married arms.
And they that made the match, bawds to thy lust:
Ay, now you hang the head, shouldst ha' done so before,
Than these had not been bastards, thou a whore.

sp.speaker: Bue.
sp.l: I cannot brooked no longer, sir you do not well in this?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Ha slave.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: 'Tis not the aim of gentry to bring forth,
Such harsh unrelished fruit unto their wives,
And to their pretty pretty children by my troth.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: How rascal.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Sir I must tell you, your progenitors
Two of the which these years were servant to,
Had not such mists before their understanding,
Thus to behave themselves.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: And you'll control me sir.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Ay, ay, will.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: You rogue.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: I 'tis, I will tell you 'tis ungently done
Thus to defame your wife, abuse your children,
Wrong them, you wrong yourself, are they not yours?

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Pretty, pretty impudence in faith,

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Her whom your are bound to love, to rail against,
These whom you are bound to keep, to spurn like dogs,
And you were not my master, I would tell you.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: What slave.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Put up your bird-spit, tut I fear it not,
In doing deeds so base, so vild as these,
'Tis but a kna, kna, kna.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Rogue.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Tut howsoever, 'tis a dishonest part,
And in defence of these I throw off duty

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Good butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Peace honest mistress, I will say you are wronged,
Prove it upon him, even in his blood, his bones,
His guts, his maw, his throat, his entrails.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: You runagate of threescore,

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: 'Tis better than a knave of three and twenty,

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Patience be my buckler,
As not to file my hands in villain's blood,
You knave slave-trencher-groom
Who is your master?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: You if you were a master.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Off with your coat then, get you fort a doors.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: My coat sir.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: I your coat slave.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: 'Sfoot when you hate, 'tis but a threadbare coat,
And there 'tis for you: know that I scorn
To wear his livery is so worthy born,
And live so base a life, old as I am,
I'll rather be a beggar than your man,
And there's your service for you.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Away, out of my door: away.
So, now your champions gone, minx thou hadst better ha' gone
Quick unto thy grave.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.l: O me, that am no cause of it.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Then have suborned that slave to lift his hands against me.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: O me, what shall become of me?

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: I'll teach you tricks for this, ha you a companion.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: My heart not suffer me to leave my honest mistress and her pretty children.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I'll mark thee for a strumpet, and thy bastards.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: What will you do to them sir.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: The devil in thy shape come back again.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: No, but an honest servant sir will take this coat,
And wear it with this sword to safeguard these,
And pity them, and I am woe for you,
But will not suffer
The husband viperlike to pray on them.
That love her, and have cherished him as these,
As they have you.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Slave.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: I will not humour you,
Fight with you, and lose my life or these
Shall taste your wrong whom you are bound to love.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Out of my doors slave.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: I will not, but will stay and wear this coat,
And do you service whether you will or no.
I'll wear this sword to, and be champion,
To fight for her in spite of any man.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: You shall. You shall be my master sir.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: No, I desire it not,
I'll pay you duty even upon my knee,
But lose my life, ere these oppressed I'll see.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Yes goodman slave, you shall be master,
Lie with my wife, and get more bastards, do, do, do.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: O me.

sp.speaker: Scar
sp.l: Turns the world upside down, that men o'erbear their
Masters, it does, it does.
For even as Judas sold his master Christ,
Men buy and sell their wives at highest price,
What will you give me? what will you give me? what will you give me?
O, mistress,
My soul weeps, though mine eyes be dry,
To see his fall and your adversity,
Some means I have left, which I'll relieve you with,
Into your chamber, and if comfort be a kin
To such great grief, comfort your children.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: I thank thee butler, heaven when he please,
Send death unto the troubled a blessed ease.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Introth I know not if it be good or ill,
That with this endless toil I labour thus,
'Tis but the old times ancient conscience
That would do no man hurt, that makes me do't,
If it be sin that I do pity these,
If it be sin I have relieved his brothers,
Have played the thief with them to get their food,
And made a luckless marriage for his sister,
Intended for her good, heaven pardon me.
But if so, I am sure they are greater sinners,
That made this match, and were unhappy men,
For they caused all, and may heaven pardon them.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.l: Who's within here.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Sir William, kindly welcome.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.l: Where is my kinsman Scarborrow?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Sooth he's within sir, but not very well.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: His sickness?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: The hell of sickness, troubled in his mind.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.l: I guess the cause of it,
But cannot now intend to visit him,
Great business for my sovereign hasts me hence,
Only this letter from his lord and guardian to him,
Whose inside I do guess, tends to his good,
At my return I'll see him, so farewell.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Whose inside I do guess turns to his good,
He shall not see it now then, for men's minds
Perplexed like his, are like land-troubling-winds,
Who have no gracious temper.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: O butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: What's the fright now?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Help straight, or on the tree of shame
We both shall perish for the robbery.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: What is't revealed man?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Not yet good butler, only my brother Thomas
In spleen to me ▪ that would not suffer him
To kill our elder brother, had undone us
Is riding now to sir John Harcop straight, to disclose it.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Heart, who would rob with sucklings:
Where did you leave him?

sp.speaker: John
sp.l: Now taking horse to ride to Yorkshire.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: I'll stay his journey, lest I meet a hanging.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: I'll parley with the devil: ay, I will,
He gives his council freely, and the cause
He for his clients pleads, goes always with them,
He in my cause shall deal then: and I'll ask him
Whether a cormorant may have stuffed chests
And see his brother starve: why he'll say I,
The less they give, the more I gain thereby.

div.l: Their souls, their souls, their souls.
How now master? Nay, you are my master?
Is my wife's sheets warm? Does she kiss well?

sp.speaker: Bat.
sp.l: Good sir.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Foe, makt not strange for in these days,
There's many men lie in their master's sheets,
And so may you in mine and yet: your business sir?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: There's one in civil habit sir, would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: In civil habit.

sp.speaker: But:
sp.l: He is of seemly rank sir, and calls himself
By the name of doctor Baxtor of Oxford.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: That man undid me, he did blossoms blow
Whose fruit proved poison, though 'twas good in show,
With him I'll parley, and disrobe my thoughts
Of this wild frenzy that becomes me not:
A table, candles, stools, and all things fit,
I know he comes to chide me, and I'll hear him,
with our sad conference we will call up tears,
Teach doctors rules, instruct succeeding years:
Usher him in:
Heaven spare a drop from thence where's bounties throng
Give patience to my soul, inflame my tongue.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: God master Scarborow.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: You are most kindly welcome, sooth ye are.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: I ha important business to deliver you.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: And I have leisure to attend your hearing.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Sir, you know I married you.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: I know you did sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: At which you promised both to God and men,
Your life unto your spouse should like snow,
That falls to comfort, not to overthrow,
And love unto your issue should be like
The dew of heaven, that hurts not though it strike,
When heaven and men did witness and record
'Twas an eternal oath, no idle word ▪
Heaven being pleased therewith, blessed you with children,
And at heaven's blessings, all good men rejoice.
So that god's chair and footstool, heaven and earth
Made offering at your nuptials as a knot
To mind you of your vow, oh break it not?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: 'Tis very true.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Now sir, from this your oath and band,
Faith's pledge, and seal of conscience you ha' run,
Broken all contracts, and the forfeiture,
Justice hath now in suit against your soul,
Angels are made the jurors, who are witnesses
Unto the oath you took, and God himself
Maker of marriage, he that sealed the deed,
As a firm lease unto you during life,
Sirs now as judge of your transgression,
The world informs against you with this voice,
If such sins reign, what mortals can rejoice.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: What then ensues to me?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: A heavy doom, whose executions
Now served upon your conscience, that ever
you shall feel plagues whom time shall not dissever,
As in a map your eyes see all your life,
Bad words, worse deeds, false oaths, and all the injuries,
You ha' done unto your soul, then comes your wife,
Full of woes drops, and yet as full of pity,
Who though she speaks not, yet her eyes are swords,
That cut your heartstrings, and then your children.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: O, oho, o.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Who what they cannot say talk in their looks,
You have made us up, but as misfortune's books,
Whom other men may read in, when presently,
Tasked by yourself, you are not like a thief,
Astonished being accused, but scorch with grief,

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Ay, ay, I.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Here stands your wife's tears.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Where?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: And you fry for them, here lie your children's wants.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Here?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: For which you pine in conscience burn,
And wish you had been better, or never born.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Does all this happen to a wretch like me.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Both this and worse, your soul eternally
Shall live in torment, though the body die.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: I shall ha' need of drink then butler,

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Nay all your sins are on your children laid,
For the offences that the father made.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Are they sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Be sure they are.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Butler.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Go fetch my wife and children hither.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.p: I'll read a letter to the Doct. too, he's a divine? I he's a divine.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.p: I see his mind is troubled, and have made bold with duty to read a letter tending to his good, have made his brother's friends: both which I will conceal till better temper: he sends me for his wife and children, shall I fetch 'em.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p:
He's a divine, and this divine did marry me, that's
good, that's good,

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Master Scarborrow.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.p: I'll be with you straight sir,

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: I will obey him,
If any thing doth happen that is ill,
Heaven bear me record 'tis against butlers will.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: And this divine did marry me,
Whose tongue should be the key to open truth,
As god's ambassador. Deliver, deliver, deliver.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Master Scarborrow.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: I'll be with you straight sir,
Salvation to afflicted consciences,
And not give torment to contented minds,
Who should be lamps to comfort out our way,
And not like fire-drakes to lead men astray,
Ay, I'll be with you straight sir.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Here's your wife and children sir?

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Give way then,
I ha' my lesson perfect, leave us here ▪

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Yes I will go, but I will be so near,
To hinder the mishap the which I fear.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Now sir, you know this gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Kind mistress Scarborrow,

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Nay pray you keep your seat, for you shall hear,
The same affliction you ha' taught me fear,
Due to yourself.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: To me sir.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: To you sir,
You matched me to this gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: I know I did sir.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: And you will say she is my wife then.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: I ha' reason sir, because I married you.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: O that such tongues should ha' the time to lie,
Who teach men how to live, and how to die,
Did not you know my soul had given my faith,
In contract to another, and yet you
Would join this loom unto unlawful twists.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: But sir,
You that can see a mote within my eye,
And with a cassock blind your own defects,
I'll teach you this, 'tis better to do ill,
That's never known to us, then of self will,
And these all these in thy seducing eye,
As scorning life make 'em be glad to die.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Me Scarborrow.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Here will I write, that they which marry wives,
Unlawful live with strumpets all their lives.
Here will I seal the children that are born,
From wombs unconsecrate, even when their soul
Has her infusion, it registers they are foul,
And shrinks to dwell with them, and in my close,
I'll show the world, that such abortive men,
Knit hands without free tongues look red like them
Stand you and you, to acts most tragical,
Heaven has dry eyes, when sin, makes sinners fall.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Help master Scarborrow,

sp.speaker: Child.
sp.l: Father.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Husband.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: These for thy act should die, she for my Clare,
Whose wounds stare thus upon me for revenge.
These to be rid from misery, this from sin,
And thou thyself shalt have a push amongst 'em,
That made heaven's word a packhorse to thy tongue.
Cotest scripture to make evils shine like good,
And as I send you thus with worms to dwell,
Angels applaud it as a deed done well.

sp.speaker: But ▪
sp.l: Stay him, stay him.
What will you do sir.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Make fat worms of stinking carcases,
What hast thou to do with it?

div.stage: Enter Ilford and his wife, the two brothers, and sir William Scarborrow

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Look who are here sir.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Injurious villain that prevent'st me still.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: They are your brothers and alliance sir.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: They are like full ordinance then, who once discharged,
Afar off give a warning to my soul,
That I had done them wrong.

sp.speaker: Sir will
sp.l: Kinsman.

sp.speaker: Brother and sister.
sp.l: Brother.

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: Husband.

sp.speaker: Child.
sp.l: Father.

sp.speaker: Scar,
sp.l: Hark how their words like bullets shoot me thorough
And tell me I have undone 'em, this side might say.
We are in want, and you are the cause of it,
This points at me, yore shame unto your house,
This tongue says nothing, but her looks do tell,
She's married but as those that live in hell:
Whereby all eyes are but misfortunes pipe,
Filled full of woe by me, this feels the stripe.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Yet look sir,
Here's your brother's hand in hand, whom I ha' knit so.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: And look sir here's my husband's hand in mine,
And I rejoice in him, and he in me.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.l: I say coz what is past, the way to bliss,
For they know best to mend, that know amiss,

sp.speaker: Ka.
sp.l: We kneel, forget, and say if you but love us,
You gave us grief for future happiness.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: What all this to my conscience?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Ease ▪ promise of succeeding joy to you,
Read but this letter.

sp.speaker: Sir Will.
sp.l: Which tells you that your lord and guardians dead.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Which tells you that he knew he did you wrong,
Was grieved fort, and for satisfaction
Hath given you double of the wealth you had.

sp.speaker: Bro.
sp.l: Increased our portions.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Given me a dowry too.

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: And that he knew,
Your sin was his, the punishment his due.

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: All this is here,
Is heaven so gracious to sinners then?

sp.speaker: But.
sp.l: Heaven is, and has his gracious eyes,
To give men life not like intrapping spies.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Your hand, yours, yours, to you my soul, to you a kiss,
Introth I am sorry I ha' strayed amiss,
To whom shall I be thankful. All silent:
None speak: whist: why then to God,
That gives men comfort as he gives his rod,
Your portions I'll see paid, and I will love you,
You three I'll live withal, my soul shall love you,
You are an honest servant, sooth you are,
To whom, I these and all must pay amends,
But you I will admonish in cool terms,
Let not promotions hope, be as a string,
To tie your tongue, or let lose it to sting.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: From hence it shall not sir.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Then husbands thus shall nourish with their wives.

sp.speaker: Ilf.
sp.l: As thou and I will wench.
Brothers in brotherly love thus link together,

sp.speaker: Sca.
sp.l: Children and servants pay their duty thus.
And all are pleased.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We are.

sp.speaker: Scar.
sp.l: Then if all these be so,
I am new wed so ends old marriage woe,
And in your eyes so lovingly being wed,
We hope your hands will bring us to our bed.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
